NFL News: Free-agent RB Chris Johnson says he plans to return for the 2018 season and has no intention to retire.
When asked about the possibility of hanging up the cleats, Johnson quickly denied the thought and expressed confidence in his ability to produce for an NFL team. “I’m not done yet,” Johnson said. “I am still going strong. I got too much juice left.” Johnson, 32, initially signed a one-year contract to return to Arizona last July, but was released coming out of the preseason. However, Johnson wasn’t unemployed long as the Cardinals re-signed him on September 12th.
Johnson struggled to produce for the Cardinals and lost playing time to Kerwynn Williams in the absence of David Johnson, which ultimately led to his release a month later.
Johnson appeared in four games this season (three starts) and rushed for 114 yards on 45 carries (2.5 YPC-career-low). Johnson also caught five passes for 43 yards.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the Miami Dolphins do not plan to release C Mike Pouncey this offseason, despite his $9M cap hit for the 2018 season.
Pouncey, 28, is set to enter the third year of his 5-year/$44.75M contract and stands to make a base salary of $7.95M for the upcoming season.
There has been some concern regarding Pouncey’s hip injury that has forced him to miss playing time in previous seasons, but that won’t prompt the Dolphins to part ways with him.
Pouncey appeared in all 16 games this past season, but one doctor went as far to say that he would have to retire in the near future as a result of his lingering hip injury. In addition, other medical officials have informed Pouncey that he will likely require a hip replacement in the coming years from all the wear and tear he’s absorbed over the course of his NFL career.

With all that being said, Pouncey intends to play in the upcoming season and expects to remain a member of the Dolphins.

UPDATE: According to reports, the Washington Redskins have informed free-agent OLB Junior Galette that they will not be re-signing him.
Redskins senior VP of player personnel Doug Williams said he recently informed Galette of their decision to move on from him: “I did tell him we were going in another direction, and he was very thankful,” Williams said at the NFL owners meeting in Orlando on Sunday. “He had two Achilles’ injuries, and we stuck by him. We gave him a chance, and he’s very appreciative of it. He told me, ‘Thank you. If it wasn’t for you, I don’t know whether I’d still be here,’ so it was a good conversation.” This comes as no surprise as the Redskins reportedly rescinded their contract offer to Galette on Friday.

NFL News: Chargers impending free-agent S Tre Boston plans to test the open market next month, but has expressed interest in returning to Los Angeles.
Boston joined SiriusXM NFL Radio and was asked if he had any interest in re-signing with the Chargers. “Of course, L.A. is definitely somewhere I would love to be, but it’s a business,” Boston said on SiriusXM NFL Radio, according to Pro Football Talk. “Everybody knows how that goes. I want to find somewhere that I fit in well, somewhere that we have a chance of going to the Super Bowl.” Boston then took to twitter to clarify his comments about playing for a super bowl contender: “Also for all the 12 Charger Fans who took my quote out of context. Where do I say the Chargers aren’t a team I fit well in with and can’t make it to the SB? I’m obviously talking if I had to move on. Thanks for the fans who understand.” Boston, 25, enjoyed a breakout campaign this past season after signing a one-year/$900K contract with the Chargers last offseason and will now be looking to cash in.
Boston appeared in 16 games (15 starts) and recorded 79 total tackles, five interceptions, and eight pass defenses.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: Giants S Landon Collins confirmed that he will undergo a second surgery to repair his fractured forearm.
_______________________________________________________ “I hate surgery,” Collins said, via Stapleton. “And then I’m thinking I’m fine and excited about this season, being on the field for OTAs [organized team activity]. It’s a bone. It’s going to come back stronger, so it shouldn’t affect nothing I’m trying to do [moving forward].” Regarding his expiring rookie contract, Collins added he is letting the situation play out with GM Dave Gettleman and his agent. “I‘m just letting it just work itself out. I’m not really going through the negotiating part,” Collins said. “I’m going to leave that between [general manager] Dave Gettleman and my agent and then go from there. From that point on, I’m just here trying to make new friends with my boys, new relationships and be a captain like I’ve always been.” Collins suffered a fractured forearm in Week 16 and underwent surgery to repair the injury. However, he is still experiencing discomfort in his forearm, which has prompted him to undergo another procedure that will keep him sidelined for 6-8 weeks.
Collins will miss all of OTAs, but expects to be cleared for the start of Training Camp.
Collins, 24, started 15 games for the Giants this past season and recorded 104 combined tackles, two interceptions, six pass defenses, one forced fumble and two fumble recoveries.
Stay tuned for more.

With the 2018 salary cap set at $177.2M, here is the updated list of available cap space for each team. (via spotrac)
The “Top 51 Cap” in the first column indicates how much money the team is currently paying to their top-51 highest paid players on their roster. In the offseason, all players that aren’t included in the top-51 highest paid category do not count against the team’s salary cap. During the regular season all player salaries count against the cap.
So under the offseason salary cap rule of the “Top 51”, each team’s available cap space is listed in the second column.

NFL News: Seahawks LT Duane Brown says he was “disrespected” by the Houston Texans due to their unwillingness to restructure his contract before he was traded.
_______________________________________________________ "It was bigger than football for me at that point," Brown said, via the Houston Chronicle. "I was disrespected. I can't walk in that building and only play football. You have to interact with these people at some point. I'm not one of those people that can fake my way through that [stuff]. I can't. It was too far gone, and the departure was needed. It had nothing to do with me wanting to get out of Houston or leave my teammates. Not at all.” Brown wanted to re-do his contract, which was set to expire in 2019, but the Texans stood firm. The standoff led to animosity. "I wanted to finish my career there, and I wanted security doing that," Brown said. "I made it known right at the end of the season. There was no conversation throughout the whole offseason about it, which is why I didn't show up to anything. There was a conversation around minicamp where they said we can't do deals with two years left, but they've done it before. Basically they were like, 'We've done it before but you're not worth that.' So, I'm like, 'OK, well, I'm not coming to anything then.'" Brown was traded to the Seattle Seahawks on October 30th.

NFL News: Packers RT Bryan Bulaga (ACL) says his rehab will take him all the way up to the start of training camp.
Bulaga suffered a torn ACL in Week 9 vs. Lions and is not expecting to be cleared before the Packers open training camp in late July.
As for his future in Green Bay for the upcoming season, Bulaga says he and his agent have not heard anything from team officials and is expecting to return. “My agents were in Indy [at the combine] last week, and we haven’t heard anything,” Bulaga said, via ESPN.com. “I guess my thought process on all of that is, ‘No news is good news.’ To me, I’m getting ready to help the Green Bay Packers win football games next year. That’s what I’m doing. I’m preparing myself, getting myself back ready to help this team win football games. To me, I’m not even really worried about any financial aspects of what’s going on or contract talks. That’s out of my hands. We haven’t heard anything but even if we did, I’m not even worried about that. I’m more worried about getting back, getting ready as soon as possible and being ready to contribute when I get back.” Bulaga, 28, is set to enter the fourth year of his 5-year/$33.75M contract and stands to make base salaries of $5.85M and $5.8M for the 2018 and 2019 seasons.
Bulaga will carry a $7.903M cap hit for the upcoming season.

NFL News: Former Browns QB Johnny Manziel revealed on “Good Morning America” that he is battling bipolar and is receiving medication to treat it.
Manziel also reiterated his desire to return to football: “I am watching all the other guys doing what I want to be doing and I am sitting on a couch being a loser,” Manziel said, via ESPN.com.

Manziel says he was diagnosed with bipolar disorder “about a year ago” and added that he’s stopped drinking, which he had been using to deal with depression. “At the end of the day I can’t help that my wires are a little bit differently crossed than yours, I can’t help my mental makeup of the way that I was created,” Manziel said. “But I know if I stay on these meds and I continue to do what I am doing right now … I think my dad, my mom, I think [girlfriend Bre Tiesi], would all agree that they see a drastic change.” Manziel says he wants to get back to playing football, which is something he’s enjoyed and embraced for so long. “I don’t know what kind of comeback it will be,” Manziel said, “but I know I want to get back on a football field to what brought me so much joy in my life and it makes me happy doing as my job.” Manziel had been negotiating a deal with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats of the CFL, but his self-imposed deadline passed without an agreement being finalized.
Manziel, 25, is a former 2014 first-round pick of the Cleveland Browns and has not played in the NFL since 2015.

NFL Picks📊: Super Bowl 52

Philadelphia Eagles vs. New England Patriots
Brady and the Patriots are well known for their miraculous come-from-behind victories, but I actually believe it will be the opposite today. I expect the Patriots to get off to a fast start against an inexperienced Philadelphia team. Look for New England to roll out many different looks offensively to keep the Eagles' explosive pass-rush off balance. I believe Rex Burkhead will be the x-factor in today's matchup. Burkhead has been productive when healthy this season and his silence in their offense the last couple weeks makes me believe that he will be heavily featured today. Look for a lot of running back screens and quick passes over the middle. Those sequence of play-calls will then open up the opportunity for the Patriots to find success with running back draw plays. I expect the Eagles' defense to be aggressive with their alignments against the Patriots' high-potent offense. Malcolm Jenkins will be called upon to defend Rob Gronkowski when he is split out wide, so keep an eye on that matchup and its implications.
As for Foles and the Eagles' offense, look to see a heavy dose of the run-pass options, which has been a staple to their successful postseason. However, I do expect Doug Pederson to dial up a plethora of new plays that will put the New England defense on their heels. I believe Jay Ajayi and LeGarrette Blount will combine for over 125 rush yards against a Patriots defense that struggles to defend inside runs. I think New England will do a nice job of limiting Zach Ertz's production, but this is where I look for Nelson Agholor to come away with some big plays out of the slot.
I believe the Eagles will be playing from behind for most of the game and I expect them to close the gap in the fourth quarter as they slowly hit their stride. It will come down to the Eagles' defense having to stop Brady in the late stages of the game to give their offense a chance. However, Brady has seen it all at this stage of his career and I think he will find a way to make a game-clinching throw down the field to seal their sixth Super Bowl title. Pats win a tight one, 30-24.

Pre-Mock Draft Notes📋: It’s easy to envision the Bills making a splash in a trade-up for a quarterback, but I think they end up either retaining Taylor for the 2018 season or acquiring a veteran QB such as Nick Foles, Case Keenum, or Sam Bradford. I can definitely see Buffalo taking a quarterback later in the draft, should they pass one up in round one. With all that being said, I think they stand pat and select a pair of Iowa Hawkeyes to fulfill two of their biggest needs this offseason.
The Carolina Panthers are at risk of losing OG Andrew Norwell in free agency and if they do, acquiring a road-grading offensive guard should be a top priority come April. Will Hernandez fits the bill and would be a nice addition to help keep Cam Newton up-right next season.
Lamar Jackson is one of the many wildcard prospects in this year’s draft class and could easily be a top-15 pick. Jackson could make some sense for Buffalo at No. 21 or 22 overall, but if he’s on the board when the Saints pick at 27, there would be some crazy potential. Drew Brees is certainly very much involved in the Saints’ short-term plans, but they need to start grooming his heir for the future. Jackson is a dynamic playmaker that has the skill set to thrive under the direction of Sean Payton and quarterback guru; Pete Carmichael. Sign me up for a future Saints’ offense headlined by Alvin Kamara, Michael Thomas, and Lamar Jackson.

2018 NFL Draft🗣: Penn State RB Saquon Barkley believes he can provide another dynamic to the New York Giants’ offense.
When asked about his potential fit with the Giants, here’s what the top running back prospect had to say: "I think Eli Manning definitely has a lot in his tank left, and is an extraordinary player," the former Penn State star told PennLive.com , "and then Odell Beckham is the most exciting player in the NFL over the last three or four years, and obviously he's coming off an injury. "Then, you have a great wide receivers corps, Sterling Shepard and the tight ends (Evan Engram) and all those guys. I think I would have the success I had in college." Barkley added that it would be a tall task for opposing defenses to stop their offense, considering all the weapons they’d have in New York: "Being able to demand that attention I brought from the backfield; it's kind of hard (for defenses). What are you going to do? It's pick your poison," Barkley said. "You don't want to load the box because the wide receiving corps is so dangerous, and if I went up there and had success, you'd have to factor in the run game. It's kind of a two-man game if I'd be able to have success." _______________________________________________________
The Giants currently hold the No. 2 overall pick of the 2018 NFL Draft. If they choose to use it on Barkley, they won’t have to question his motivation to thrive in their offensive system.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, Browns HC Hue Jackson says “everyone” is still in play at No. 1 overall.
Many league sources believe the Browns have already decided on a specific signal caller with their top pick.
However, Jackson laughed at the reports stating that they’ve settled on Wyoming QB Josh Allen as their choice. He reiterated that Allen, Sam Darnold, Josh Rosen and Baker Mayfield all remain in the mix as GM John Dorsey has yet to make a firm decision. “If there was a consensus John had come to, he would’ve told me,” Jackson said, via Cleveland.com. “That’s not the case. … When John Dorsey goes dark, he goes dark.” There has been growing belief that Dorsey is heavily leaning Allen’s way at No. 1 overall, but that’s not something the Browns will confirm or deny.
It’s smoke-screen season.

Saints WR Cameron Meredith admitted that he was a little surprised by the Bears’ decision to not match the Saints’ offer sheet earlier in the week. “You know, it’s my home city, so you know of course a bit of a disappointment,” Meredith said Friday, via Joel A. Erickson of the Advocate. “So it was a surprise, but at the end of the day I signed that letter agreement with the Saints knowing that was a possibility. I was expecting to be a Saint, but if the Bears matched, it wouldn’t have been bad either.” As for his knee, Meredith said he hasn’t had any setbacks and expects to be ready for the start of the season. “I have not had any setbacks along the recovery process. I’m gaining strength day by day,” Meredith said. “The main objective for me is to do as much as I can with the trainers to get ready for the season. My goal is to try and get back to training camp, but as long as there aren’t any setbacks or anything like that, it should not be any problem.” Meredith did not want to speculate as to why the Bears’ evaluation of his knee came back as a concern. “That’s not my place to say,” Meredith said. “From what I know and what I’ve been told, I’m right on schedule, and I haven’t had any setbacks, and I should be ‘A okay,’ at least from the medical standpoint.” The Bears placed an original-round tender on Meredith, which means they let him walk for nothing by not matching his 2-year/$10M offer sheet.
Meredith, 25, suffered a torn ACL in the preseason that kept him sidelined for the entire 2017 season.

In 2016, Meredith started 10 games for the Bears and caught 66 passes for 888 yards and four touchdowns.

UPDATE: According to reports, the Washington Redskins are considering placing the franchise tag on QB Kirk Cousins to keep him from testing the open market as an unrestricted free-agent.
Several days after acquiring Alex Smith from the Kansas City Chiefs, the Redskins appear to be discussing the idea of placing the franchise tag on Cousins in attempt to acquire draft compensation via trade.
However, this is a complicated situation for the Redskins because Cousins could delay signing the franchise tag, which would leave the team on the hook with his $34.5M base salary as free agency begins in mid-March.
Another hurdle for the Redskins to overcome in this scenario, is they’d need Cousins and a team to agree to a long-term contract extension before any trade is completed. This needs to be done to ensure the receiving team that they are not acquiring Cousins as a one-year rental. If he wanted to, Cousins could decide against negotiating a long-term deal with an interested team to delay the process of a deal or ultimately wipe away a potential trade from happening.
At this point, odds are stacked against the Redskins to tag and trade Cousins, but it appears they are willing to exhaust all options before letting him walk in free agency for nothing in return.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Cowboys owner Jerry Jones is expected to meet with WR Dez Bryant on Friday to discuss his future with the team.
The lingering question of Bryant’s status in Dallas will finally come to an end on Friday. The Cowboys will open OTAs on Monday, so Jones’ scheduled meeting with Bryant makes a lot of sense.
If Bryant were to suffer any season-ending injury on the team’s premises, his $12.5M salary would become fully guaranteed for the 2018 season. That is why the Cowboys will have a decision before their offseason program gets underway. The only thing left to find out is if he’ll be playing elsewhere in 2018.
There is “growing sense” within the Cowboys’ organization that Bryant will be released on Friday. Several team executives have reportedly been making a strong case for the Joneses to sever ties with the 3-time Pro-Bowl wideout. They argue that he’s regressed physically and don’t believe he can regain his dominant form due to recent injuries and his inability to create separation at the line of scrimmage.
Bryant is set to enter the fourth year of his 5-year/$70M contract ($45M guaranteed) and is due a base salary of $12.5M over the final two years of the agreement. Bryant is scheduled to carry a $16.5M cap hit for the upcoming season.

If the Cowboys do indeed release Bryant, they would free up $8.5M of cap space, while absorbing $8M of dead money. They can also designate him as a Post-June 1 release that would free up $12.5M of cap space, while splitting up his $8M of dead money over the 2018 and 2019 seasons ($4M each year). Bryant, 29, started all 16 games this past season and caught 69 passes for 838 yards and six touchdowns.

NFL News: According to reports, the Chicago Bears are expected to part ways with QB Mike Glennon this offseason.
While the Bears didn’t anticipate Glennon being their long-term answer at quarterback, they certainly expected him to be their starter for at least a couple of seasons when they signed him to a 3-year/$45M ($18.5M guaranteed) deal last March.
However, the Bears surprisingly opted to trade up for Mitchell Trubisky in the 2017 NFL Draft and it clearly impacted Glennon’s immediate future in Chicago.
In the wake of selecting Trubisky 2nd overall, former Bears HC John Fox repeatedly stated that Glennon was their starting quarterback. As training camp started, Glennon struggled and was never able to solidify himself as the team’s No. 1 quarterback.
Glennon’s struggles continued into the 2017 regular season as he threw for 833 passing yards, four touchdowns and five interceptions to go along with a 66.4 completion percentage through his first four starts with the Bears. Chicago went 1-3 with Glennon as their starter and that’s what prompted a quarterback change with Trubisky getting the nod for the rest of the season.
With the Trubisky era in full swing in the Windy City entering the offseason, Glennon’s one year stint appears to be all but over.
Glennon, 28, is set to enter the second year of his 3-year deal and stands to make base salaries of $12.5M and $12M for the 2018 and 2019 seasons.

NFL Picks📊: NFC Championship
No. 2 Minnesota Vikings @ No. 1 Philadelphia Eagles Who would have thought Case Keenum and Nick Foles would be dueling it out for a chance to play in Super Bowl 52? Yeah, not many of us, if any. While it's baffling, to say the least, we can't take anything away from the two Texas natives that have battled their way through adversity to reach this point in their careers. It's what makes this matchup odd, yet entertaining.
As for the matchup, I do anticipate this game being a defensive battle. The Eagles have the 4th ranked defense and the Vikings boast the top-ranked defense, so there is a reason to believe that this one will come down to which unit can win the turnover battle. A slow offensive start cannot be in the cards for the Eagles today. It's easier said than done going up against Minnesota's elite unit, but if they put all the weight on their defense again, it won't bode well for their chances to advance. So I expect Doug Pederson to dial up a variety of calls that will work the middle of the field. Foles will be given plenty of RPO's early and often, but I do anticipate the Eagles using screenplays to help alleviate Minnesota's fierce pass-rush. As for the Vikings' offense, they'll look to establish their run game with Latavius Murray and Jerick McKinnon. The Eagles' secondary has drastically improved each week, but they are still susceptible to giving up big plays down the field. Minnesota has the personnel with Stefon Diggs and Adam Thielen to exploit that weakness, so I expect Keenum to connect on a long ball for six. I think Jake Elliott will be a busy man tonight, as the Eagles will rely on his kicking ability to keep them in the game. This game will be determined in the trenches and I think the Vikings' ability to run the ball consistently in the second half will help them control the clock and manage field position. In result, it will pin the Eagles' offense deep into their own territory on many occasions which will produce a costly turnover in the fourth quarter for Philly. Minnesota ices the game with a late score to make it 27-19 and that will secure them their first trip to the Super Bowl since 1977.

UPDATE: According to reports, Free-agent QB Johnny Manziel is likely to sign a two-year deal with a CFL team if he doesn’t receive an NFL opportunity this offseason.
Manziel played in a football game for the first time in over two years as part of The Spring League on Saturday.
Manziel finished the day completing 9 of 15 pass attempts for 82 yards and one touchdown.

Manziel admitted that he was disappointed by the sloppiness of the game, but reiterated his joy to be playing the sport he loves: “It’s disappointing, some of the things that happened, but nevertheless, it’s a huge step for me,” Manziel said, via ESPN.com. “I put pads back on. A lot of people wrote me off just to even get to this point. I’m definitely emotional about it. I’m definitely happy about it. This isn’t the end goal for me, but I’m having fun again. I have a smile on my face.” There were reportedly 17 NFL teams with scouts in attendance for the Spring League’s practices.
Manziel, 25, is a former 2014 first-round pick of the Cleveland Browns.

NFL News: According to reports, the New York Jets are expected to release DE Muhammad Wilkerson before the new league year.
When the Jets inked Wilkerson to a lucrative 5-year/$86M contract extension ($53M guaranteed) in July of 2016, they anticipated him being the anchor of their defense for the foreseeable future. However, his poor attitude and declining play changed the landscape of his future as a Jet.
Wilkerson showed up late to several team meetings this past season and exuded what team officials call “lackluster discipline”. In result, Jets HC Todd Bowles benched Wilkerson for the final three games of the regular season for conduct detrimental to the team. It was also a business decision for the Jets to sit Wilkerson, considering the injury clauses in his contract that could have prompted the team to pay him guaranteed money if he had suffered an injury.
Wilkerson, 28, has made $37M the last two seasons under his current contract and is scheduled to make a base salary of $16.75M for the 2018 season. Wilkerson’s salary for the upcoming season will become guaranteed on March 16th, so the Jets will make his release official before then.
The Jets will save $11M against the cap by releasing Wilkerson, while absorbing $9M of dead money.
Wilkerson appeared in 13 games this season (12 starts) and recorded 26 tackles, 3.5 sacks, one interception and four pass defenses.
Stay tuned for more.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, Several NFL teams have red-flagged Florida State OLB/DE Josh Sweat due to previous knee injuries.
Sweat (6’4”, 251 lbs) has risen up many draft boards due to his explosive performance at the scouting combine, but previous knee injuries have some NFL teams uneasy about his upcoming professional career.
Sweat dislocated his left knee during his senior year of high school. In addition, Sweat suffered a torn ACL in the same knee.
Sweat later sustained a torn meniscus in his left knee during his sophomore season at Florida State and was sidelined for two weeks.
Since then, Sweat has worn a protective brace on his left knee for additional support. While playing with the brace never hindered his production in college, a number of NFL teams are concerned about how his knee will hold up at the next level, considering all the trauma it has absorbed over the years.
Sweat conducted several of his private workouts without the knee brace, so league scouts were encouraged with his ability to perform without it.
With that being said, if Sweat experiences a minor draft day slide, it’ll be because of teams’ concern with his left knee.
Sweat is currently projected to be a 2nd/3rd-round pick.
Stay tuned for more.

2018 NFL Draft: Wyoming QB Josh Allen tells Rich Cimini of ESPN that he would relish the opportunity to play for the Jets. “Absolutely,” Allen said. “They’re a couple of pieces away from winning a lot of football games. I really enjoyed the coaching staff and I think it would be a really good fit. I think they’ve got some weapons on offense and they have a really young defense that’s ready to win right now.” Allen says the Jets gave him some plays to learn and then had him go through them on the board during his official pre-draft visit. “First they got me on the board,” said Allen. “They gave me a quick lesson on their offense and how they handle themselves, then I went up on the board and regurgitated it back to them. I talked about some of my plays and the things we did at Wyoming. Then we went down on the field and threw a lot of footballs. They had some free agents come out and I made all the throws, so there’s no question about that.” _______________________________________________________
As for playing in New York, Allen says he isn’t phased by the scrutiny that can come with playing in the top market in the country. “I think where I come from is going to help me with a market such as New York,” Allen said. “I’m not afraid of the media. I think I know how to handle them because I’ve been around them enough. I understand the New York media is a lot more magnified than most markets, but I’m up for that challenge. I’d definitely be suitable and I’d be primed for a market like that.“ _______________________________________________________
There is a strong possibility that Allen will go No. 1 overall to the Cleveland Browns, but if he remains on the board when the Jets pick at 3, he’ll certainly be considered along with Oklahoma’s Baker Mayfield and UCLA’s Josh Rosen.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Eagles LT Jason Peters confirmed that he will return for the 2018 season.
Peters suffered a torn ACL and MCL in Week 7 vs. Redskins which resulted in him undergoing season-ending surgery.
Peters, 36, is set to enter the second year of his 3-year/$27.75M contract and stands to make a base salary of $7.75M for the 2018 season. The final year of Peters’ contract in 2019 is a team option.
With that being said, Peters’ future in Philadelphia remains uncertain as the Eagles prepare to work with a small amount of cap space this offseason. The Eagles want to keep cap flexibility to allow them the opportunity to sign notable players such as Jay Ajayi to long-term deals in the future. Although Ajayi is under team control for the 2018 season, the Eagles still want to leave the door open for working out a potential contact extension before he hits the open market in 2019.
Patrick Robinson is another player the Eagles have interest in signing to a multi-year deal this offseason as he prepares to become an unrestricted free-agent in March.
In result, the Eagles could look to move on from Peters, which would clear the way for Halapoulivaati Vaitai to be their full-time starter at Left Tackle.
Peters acknowledged the possibility of playing elsewhere next season, but added that it will not alter his decision to return.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, the NFL is scheduled to make a ruling on Bengals’ QB A.J. McCarron’s free-agent status on Thursday.
McCarron, a former 2014 fifth-round pick, is trying to become an unrestricted free-agent this offseason and is challenging the Bengals’ decision to place him on the Non-Football Injury list during his rookie season. McCarron claims he was healthy when the Bengals placed him on the NFI list back in 2014, which prevented him from getting the necessary amount of accrued service to become an unrestricted free-agent next month.
As of now, McCarron is scheduled to become a restricted free-agent, which allows the Bengals the right of refusal to any contract he receives on the open market. In addition, the Bengals will have the option the place a first or second-round tender on McCarron, which would permit any team to provide a top-round draft pick to Cincinnati if they sign him.

NFL News: Giants GM Dave Gettleman says he is open to trading their No. 2 overall pick in the upcoming 2018 NFL Draft.
_______________________________________________________ "Are we open for business? You know, whatever. Any decision I make is going to be in the best interest of the New York Football Giants. Plain and simple," he said. "So if someone makes me an offer I can't refuse, would I move back? Depends on who is there." In the same breath, Gettleman reiterated that he will not be willing trade down if they believe an impact player sits on the board when they go on the clock. "Again, if there is a guy worthy of being the second pick of the draft and what we're basically saying and answering that question to the affirmative, you're drafting what you think is going to be a Hall of Fame player," Gettleman added. "So you can't get too cute about that thing." Gettleman, 67, was hired to become the Giants’ general manager on December 28th, 2017.
Stay tuned for more.
________________________________________________________

NFL News: Eagles DE Brandon Graham says he wants a contract extension this offseason and hopes to finish his career in Philadelphia.
_______________________________________________________
“For me, it’s all about getting as much as you can while you can play because when it’s over, it’s over,” Graham said, via Dave Zangaro of NBC Sports Philadelphia. “I know Howie [Roseman] and those guys, if they want me here, they’re going to make sure that they get me here. For me, I want to be here. Everybody knows I want to be here. They see the passion I have and I’m happy to be able to bring the trophy back to Philly. Now, it’s just all about just making sense, just getting me protected for the future. Because obviously I want to retire here and I know I’m going to retire here because I’ve been here a long time. I would love to retire here. It’s all on what they want to do. I’m just going to embrace it, whatever it is.” Graham, 29, is set to enter the final year of his 4-year/$26M contract and stands to make a base salary of $7M for the 2018 season.
Graham outplayed his contract this season as he led the team with 9.5 sacks and made the game-clinching strip sack on Patriots QB Tom Brady to close out the Eagles’ Super Bowl victory.
Graham also recorded 33 solo tackles, two forced fumbles, one fumble recovery returned for a touchdown and three pass defenses in 15 starts this season.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Steelers RB Le’Veon Bell says he has not received a contract offer anywhere close to his perceived value.
_______________________________________________________ "We're not coming to a number we both agree on -- they are too low, or I guess they feel I'm too high," Bell said. "I'm playing for strictly my value to the team. That's what I'm asking. I don't think I should settle for anything less than what I'm valued at." Bell received the franchise tag on Monday that will pay him a fully guaranteed salary of $11.866M for the upcoming season. However, Bell is still looking to be paid adequately and is seeking a deal worth $14.5M per year. Bell confirmed that he passed up the Steelers’ offer last July that included $42M guaranteed over the first three years with an average of $13.3M over the life of the deal.
Bell also reiterated that he will consider retirement if he doesn’t receive a long-term deal before the 2018 season. "I just have to decide if I'm going to play when the time comes," Bell said.

Bell once again stated the importance of guaranteed money in his next contract and does not plan to settle for anything less than his value. "I'm the one to bet on myself. And I'll do it again," Bell said. "I understand how the Steelers do contracts. Last year, I was pounding the table on guaranteed money. That's not the case. If I'm not getting guaranteed money, I want a lot more up front. ... It's year-to-year with the Steelers. Essentially if I sign a four- or five-year deal, I'm playing four or five franchise tags.” The highest paid running back in the NFL is Falcons RB Devonta Freeman, who is making an annual salary of $8.25M. Bell certainly hopes to earn almost double that salary to retire as a member of the Steelers.
Only time will tell if it can actually happen.
Bell started 15 regular season games and rushed for 1,291 yards on 321 carries (4.0 YPC) and nine touchdowns. Bell also caught 85 passes for 655 yards and two touchdowns.

NFL News: Redskins impending free-agent OLB Junior Galette says he has yet to receive a contract offer from Washington and plans to test the open market next month. “I haven’t spoken to them personally,” Galette said, via the Washington Post. “But speaking to my agent, Drew Rosenhaus, . . . he just basically said they’re pretty much gonna let me test free agency, because I’m pretty sure that if it was the other way around, I think they would have offered me a deal and nothing has been offered. There’s nothing else left for me to believe but they want me to test free agency.” Galette was once a top tier pass-rusher, as he compiled 22 sacks in his last two years with the Saints. But off-field troubles led to his departure from New Orleans and upon coming to Washington, he suffered torn Achilles tendons his first two years.
Galette appeared in all 16 games this season and recorded 14 tackles, three sacks and one forced fumble. However, Galette still believes he is an “elite” edge-rusher, despite his low numbers: “I consider myself elite,” Galette said. “You look at the numbers, it is what it is. I don’t care what you tell me. I had back-to-back [double-digit sack years] in New Orleans. I think only four players were during that span and I was on pace, had a promising career. I still do, I feel like, but pass rush is so relative. There are so many things and other variables that play into pass rush, so if you just look at my [stats] and it says that I’m top-three in the win percentage and the sacks don’t match, okay, so you look at the tape and you’re like, ‘Wait, how come the sacks don’t match?’ Well, maybe this guy deserves more playing time. If you give me more playing time, that’s how it works.” “You need the opportunities. If I had made all the sacks that I missed — about eight or nine this year — I’d have double-digit sacks, but that’s almost impossible to do. … I feel like as long as you’re disrupting the quarterback, then you show that you’re really effective in just how promising that you are with getting after the quarterback.” Galette, 29, played out his one-year/$800K deal and will become an unrestricted free-agent in March.

ICYMI: Newly signed Raiders WR Jordy Nelson opened up about his emotional breakup with the Green Bay Packers after 10 seasons.
_______________________________________________________
"I think the hurt part was, to be honest, was the unwillingness to try to make it work," Nelson said to the Wilde & Tausch Show on Monday, via ESPN. "But then again, it's a business, and they have to do what they think is best. What they need to do is to be able to move forward and prepare for the future of the Packers. But I think that was just part of it, but that's the way it is. I'm definitely not the only one that's been cut or released when you don't think it's going to happen, and it's not what you want to hear when you go into a meeting with them. But we've moved on." Nelson, 32, was set to enter the final year of a 4-year/$39M deal with the Packers this season that came with a $12M cap hit. He expected the team to approach him about a pay cut, and even considered it, up until he spoke with new GM Brian Gutekunst. "I think the [pay cut] number was part of it, but also the conversation I had in the meeting," Nelson said. "I met with Brian and had a discussion because I had to get a feel for not just the pay cut but what their plans were going forward. After that meeting, there wasn't, I don't think, much desire there. I think with the combination of both, we decided what was best for myself and my family [just] as they decided what was best for them and the Packers." _______________________________________________________
Nelson was officially released by the Packers on March 13th and inked a 2-year/$15M contract with Oakland two days later.

ICYMI🗣: Dolphins DE Robert Quinn held an introductory teleconference with the media on Thursday and discussed the end of his tenure with the Los Angeles Rams after seven seasons.
_______________________________________________________
"You commit yourself to someone and then you have a family member turn their back on you," he said. "Then you realize they appreciate you around here and you commit yourself to them. All it takes is for someone to rub you the wrong way one time and you keep moving. I've got a new family down here in Miami, and that's all I'm concerned about." Quinn said the trade to Miami is a “breath of fresh air” for him and his family: "Honestly, you don't realize you're suffocating until you can't breathe no more, so I was just glad I could have a new breath of fresh air down here in Miami," Quinn said, according to Jason Lieser of the Palm Beach Post. "It's allowed me to clear my mind and have a fresh start and a new beginning and new possibilities.”
"I'm excited for the new start. I think this was best for me and my family. Sometimes things work out funny, but they always work out for the best." When asked to clarify his comment about “suffocating” in Los Angeles, Quinn alluded to geography: "Well, how about this: I'm not a West Coast guy," he said. "I'll just put it that way." Quinn, 27, is entering the third year of his 4-year/$57M contract and is due base salaries of $10.33M and $11.81M over the final two years of the agreement. He will carry cap hits of $11.44M and $12.932M in 2018 and 2019.
Quinn appeared in 15 games for the Rams this past season (14 starts) and recorded 32 total tackles, 8.5 sacks, and two forced fumbles.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the New York Jets have USC QB Sam Darnold listed as the top quarterback on their draft board.
When the Jets acquired the No. 3 overall pick from the Indianapolis Colts, they were targeting UCLA QB Josh Rosen and Oklahoma QB Baker Mayfield.
The Jets firmly believed that they had no shot at Darnold at No. 3 when they traded up, but after the recent chatter regarding the Cleveland Browns’ affinity for Wyoming QB Josh Allen, they now have hope that he could fall to them.
This scenario is contingent upon the Browns selecting Allen at No. 1 and the New York Giants keeping their pick and taking Penn State RB Saquon Barkley or NC State DE Bradley Chubb at No. 2 overall.
Of course, a team like the Buffalo Bills can trade with the Giants to select Darnold ahead of the Jets, but that development is not guaranteed to happen.
The Jets would explore a potential move up to No. 2 with the Giants themselves, but the price will be far too rich, considering the draft capital they sent to Indianapolis.
The Jets hosted Darnold for an official Top-30 visit earlier this week and if he’s there when they go on the clock, there’s a strong chance he’s the pick. If not, it’ll either be Rosen or Mayfield, but it has not been determined which prospect they hold in higher regard between the two.
Stay tuned for more.
________________________________________________________

Injury Update: According to reports, Vikings RB Dalvin Cook (ACL) is making significant progress in his rehab and expects to be cleared for the start of training camp.
Cook a former 2017 second-round pick, suffered a torn ACL in Week 4 vs. Lions and underwent season-ending surgery on October 9th.
Cook says he has trusted his rehab and believes his knee has responded well to the treatment. “It’s a process. It’s a journey,” Cook said, via quotes distributed by the team. “It is something that you have to trust yourself and know that you did everything in your power to get your knee back the way it is at. I attack this thing every day and I did what I needed to do to get to this point. I had no doubt when I first touched the field is where I wanted to be at.” Cook has done some work on the field since offseason workouts began April 16th, and Vikings athletic trainer Eric Sugarman said Cook has “knocked the rehab out of the park.” “He’s done great job,” Sugarman said. “He’s been here every day since the injury occurred, post-surgery and really hasn’t missed a beat. . . . He’s been here with a smile on his face every day. Really just to give him the credit because he’s put in all the work to get to the point to where he is.” _______________________________________________________
In four starts, Cook rushed for 354 yards on 74 attempts (4.8 YPC) and two touchdowns to go along with 11 receptions for 90 yards.

Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Patriots OC Josh McDaniels has spoken directly to all his assistant coaches that he was planning to work with in Indianapolis.
McDaniels revealed that it was nothing about owner Jim Irsay, Andrew Luck’s potential shoulder surgery, or his impending salary that made him back out of his agreement with the Colts. McDaniels just made it clear that the Patriots convinced him to stay and felt like it was an opportunity he couldn’t pass up to remain in New England.
McDaniels reportedly went to the Patriots’ team facility on Tuesday to clean out his office and that is when Bill Belichick and Robert Kraft met with him for “hours” and let him know how they felt about him as a coach. After his visit with Belichick and Kraft, McDaniels called his wife and made the decision to return.
McDaniels will return to the Patriots as offensive coordinator and he is expected to receive a new contract that will make him the highest paid assistant coach in the NFL.
As of now, there is no plan in writing for McDaniels to succeed Bill Belichick as head coach, but there is growing sense that it is indeed the primary factor for his return.

NFL News: According to reports, the Cleveland Browns, Arizona Cardinals, Oakland Raiders, and New York Giants have expressed preliminary interest in free-agent S Tre Boston.
However, Boston joined NFL SiriusXM radio on Thursday and said that he hasn’t received any offers worth considering: “Just like a few of the other guys, we’re just not hearing anything near what we want to hear or even close,” Boston said Thursday during an appearance on SiriusXM NFL Radio. “We’re closer to veteran minimum than we are to the $7-, $8-, $9-million players we wanted to be two months ago or even eight months ago.” Boston said his agent has spoken to the Chargers about a potential return, but the two sides are currently at an impasse because “they think I’m more of a strong safety-type of player.” Boston says the lack of interest in the available safeties has been “unbelievable” to him. “It’s kind of unbelievable to me,” Boston said. “We’re talking about a position that’s needed more and more on the field in today’s game. “There are about five or six valuable starting safeties in free agency right now. But I guess it’s just trying to get us to take peanuts like the rest of them have. That’s just the business of the game.” _______________________________________________________
Boston, 25, appeared in all 16 games this past season and recorded 79 tackles, five interceptions, and eight pass defenses.

UPDATE: According to reports, Eagles DE Chris Long says he is leaning toward returning for the 2018 season, despite contemplating retirement.
Long mentioned during his Waterboys initiative in St. Louis Wednesday night, via BleedingGreenNation.com, that he’s leaning towards a return: “Yeah, well, they’re going to give me more money […] They feel bad because I gave my salary away [last season]. (joking)
No, but for me, at my age every year, it’s important to make a decision, and take self-inventory. Is your body there? Is your mind in it? Do you have the passion? Because it takes a lot. And for me, just every year, I’m a year at a time. From here on out. For however long I play.
Philly’s been awesome, like I said. They kind of adopted me as, like, family. So that definitely factors in to everything. And the chance to repeat [as Super Bowl champions].
I’m still supposedly “mulling it over,” but I’m leaning on going back and playing.
So yeah. I mean, I hadn’t even answered any questions about that but there you go.” The Eagles have offered to re-work Long’s contract for the 2018 season, but hasn’t stopped the 32-year-old defensive end from considering retirement.
Long’s potential restructured contract would pay him roughly $3M in guaranteed money for the upcoming season and would elevate his base salary to $2.5M guaranteed. Long is currently scheduled to make a base salary of $1M in non-guaranteed money. With that being said, Long has not accepted the Eagles’ offer to re-do his deal.
Long appeared in all 16 games for the Eagles this past season and recorded 28 total tackles, five sacks, and four forced fumbles.

Breaking News: According to reports, Seahawks QB Trevone Boykin is being investigated for domestic violence.
The Mansfield police department is investigating Boykin regarding a physical altercation with his girlfriend, Shabrika Bailey.

Bailey tells WFAA that she was at Boykins’ home in Mansfield last Tuesday night when they began to argue over a text message he wanted to see on her phone. “So he goes into a choke. I remember him choking me and I’m trying to calm him down. And I just couldn’t. And I blacked out. I just couldn’t calm him down at all,” Bailey told WFAA. “The pressure was just hard. The pressure got hard to where I just remember just collapsing completely. And I just woke up in a puddle of blood on the kitchen floor. My whole right side was full of blood on the kitchen floor.” Bailey suffered a broken jaw on both her left and right sides and had to be airlifted to a hospital in Dallas for further treatment because she was having difficulty breathing from a swollen and constricted airway, according to WFAA.
Boykin, 24, went undrafted out of TCU in 2016.

NFL News: Seahawks DE Michael Bennett says he’d welcome a return to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers if he’s released this offseason.
_______________________________________________________
“If anything ever happened with Seattle, I mean Tampa would be like an ideal to go back and get a chance to win a championship with those guys,” Bennett said, via JoeBucsFan.com. “But right now I’m a Seahawk, so. But it’s always cool to have your old teammates want you to back on the team because it means you made a really good impression on them and you’re really good friends.” Bennett was referring to Buccaneers’ DT Gerald McCoy’s comments about getting him back to Tampa Bay if he became available.
Bennett, 32, is due a $4M roster bonus on the fifth day of the new league year, which begins on March 14th. Bennett is signed through the 2020 season with base salaries of $1.5M in 2018, $6M in 2019 and $7.5M In 2020.
Although Bennett is under contract with the Seahawks for the next couple years, he casted doubt on his future with the team after the season by saying they are “looking to get younger.” Bennett played with the Buccaneers from 2009-2012.

NFL News: According to reports, the Carolina Panthers reworked LT Matt Kalil’s contract for the 2018 season.
Kalil, 28, inked a 5-year/$55.5M contract with the Panthers last offseason and it included a $10M bonus option for the 2018 season. While the Panthers are not wiping that bonus away, they are simply converting the $10M into a signing bonus up front.
If the Panthers did not exercise the bonus option before March 19th, that $10M would have converted to salary, which would have fully guaranteed Kalil an $11M base salary for the upcoming season.
Reworking Kalil’s contract does not create any cap relief for the Panthers, but it protects them from losing that $10M bonus money if he would have suffered an injury or retired prematurely.

NFL News: According to reports, Steelers RB Le’Veon Bell is training in Miami and plans to skip the team’s offseason program.
The Steelers placed the franchise tag on Bell for the second consecutive year and it has prompted the three-time Pro Bowl running back to skip team workouts as he continues his holdout for a long-term deal.
Bell, 26, is due to make a fully guaranteed salary of $14.544M under his franchise tender, but that isn’t appealing enough for him. Bell wants a long-term extension that will pay him $14M per year and he won’t settle for anything less. That is a primary factor as to why the Steelers and Bell haven’t progressed in contract negotiations.
Both sides will have until July 16th to finalize a new deal, but if they fail to do so, the Steelers will have to prepare to be without Bell for the entire duration of training camp.

NFL News: According to reports, Bills WR Zay Jones was arrested for felony vandalism in Los Angeles.

Jones eventually broke free and kicked through a window and attempted to climb through opening, which left him “bleeding all over the place”. Jones was restrained by his brother until police arrived and took him into custody for felony vandalism.
Jones is reportedly being held in the medical ward of L.A. County jail and it’s unclear what his condition is at this time.

NFL News: Impending free-agent K Adam Vinatieri is hoping to re-sign with the Indianapolis Colts this offseason.
_______________________________________________________ “I feel like my body is still in good shape, and I can help and contribute to a team,” Vinatieri said, via Colts.com. “So, hopefully it’s here. We’ll see. It’s a business. I understand how all that works, so we’ll see where it goes.” “I’ve been very fortunate to play on two very successful teams, franchises, over 22 years, and I enjoy playing on teams that win games,” Vinatieri added. “So, hopefully we can get back there on this team as well, but that always plays a factor. It’s fun playing in January, February. It’s fun having a chance to play for a championship.” Vinatieri said the Colts and his teammates are like family to him. “Yeah, obviously, this is a family to me,” Vinatieri said of the Colts. “I’ve been in this building for a long time. I know most of the people that work in it, if not all of them, and obviously, these guys in the locker room fighting on the field with me are my brothers as well. So, it’d be nice to stick around. My family is comfortable here, but we’ll see how it goes.” Vinatieri, 45, just finished playing out the final year of his 2-year/$6M contract and will become an unrestricted free-agent in March.

Injury Update: Texans HC Bill O’Brien says OT Derek Newton is progressing well in his rehab, but does not have a timetable for his return.
_______________________________________________________
“I would say he’s on schedule, but I wouldn’t say that he’d be able to a ton of things this spring,” Texans coach Bill O’Brien said, via John McClain of the Houston Chronicle. “Nobody’s worked harder than Derek Newton to try to get back to where he is. “He’s a very hardworking guy. The guy’s been in there every single day at 6 a.m. five days a week. He probably comes in on the weekends on his own. I would say he’s probably not [going to be] able to do a bunch of field work. He can, rehab-wise, but not in team periods and things like that.” Newton, 30, suffered ruptured patellar tendons in both knees during the 2016 season and has not played since.
Newton was initially told that his injuries could potentially end his career, but that hasn’t stopped him from vigorously rehabbing his way back into playing shape.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Cardinals S Tyrann Mathieu says GM Steve Keim asked him to take a pay cut to remain in Arizona.
Mathieu, 25, is due $18.75M in guaranteed money if he’s on the Cardinals’ roster by the third day of the new league year.
If Mathieu remains on their roster on March 14th, he’ll have his entire base salary of $5.75M for the 2018 season and $8M of his 2019 salary ($10.750M) fully guaranteed. If Mathieu is on the roster two days later, he’ll collect a $5M roster bonus.
Mathieu is set to enter the second year of his 5-year/$62.5M contract he signed in August of 2016 and is scheduled to have a $14.1M cap hit for the upcoming season.
The Cardinals are hoping for Mathieu to accept a reduced salary, but if he refuses, they’ll certainly part ways with the dynamic safety.
Trading or releasing Mathieu would save $4.8M of cap space. However, Arizona would take on $9.3M of dead money in the process.
Mathieu started all 16 games for the Cardinals this past season and logged 74 total tackles, one sack, two interceptions, one forced fumble, and seven pass defenses.

NFL News: According to reports, Some people within the Patriots’ organization believe TE Rob Gronkowski could be traded this offseason.
Greg Bedard of the Boston Sports Journal recently spoke with a “Bill Belichick-friendly source” who indicated that trading Gronkowski could be a possibility. The source told Bedard that whenever a player “begins to make Belichick contemplate life without him, Belichick starts to warm up to the idea of being without the player.” “He imagines you are gone,” Bedard’s source added. Bedard also learned that the longer Gronkowski waits to inform the Patriots of his decision to return, the less his chances are to remain a member of the team.
In addition, Gronkowski has indicated that he wants a pay raise and it’s unclear if the Patriots are open to the idea of re-working his current contract. Many league executives believe Gronkowski’s desire for more money is the main driving force behind his threat to retire.
Gronkowski, 28, is set to enter the fifth year of his 6-year/$54M deal and stands to make base salaries of $8M and $9M over the final two years of the agreement.
Gronkowski appeared in 14 games this past season and caught 69 passes for 1,084 yards and eight touchdowns.
Stay tuned for more.

2018 NFL Draft: Lions GM Bob Quinn says their signing of RB LeGarrette Blount might alter their plans to select a running back early in the draft.
When asked how the addition of Blount impacts his draft strategy at the running back position, Quinn said “it could impact it a little bit,” as Dave Birkett of the Detroit Free Press writes. “I mean, I think if we had to go a football game today we have enough running backs to be competitive,” he said. “Now, is that saying I’m not going to take one? I don’t know. Tell me who’s going to be on the board in the second, third, fourth round. I mean, I don’t know.” The Lions have been linked to LSU RB Derrius Guice with their 20th overall pick by many draft analysts, but Quinn mentioned that they may feel comfortable with the group of backs they already have.
Quinn added that he will weigh all their options in round one and did not rule out a potential trade up or back. “I think we’re going to kind of take it as it comes in the first round and see what’s there in the teens and evaluate what our options are,” Quinn said, via Carlos Monarrez of the Detroit Free Press. “I’m always in the business of getting more draft picks, if I can. … I think that’s just good for business. The more you get, the more you hit on. “So if we can acquire more picks, that would be something I look forward to.” Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Cowboys VP Stephen Jones didn’t seem too optimistic about WR Dez Bryant’s long-term future with the team during a visit with the media on Thursday night.
Here’s what Jones had to say when asked about Bryant’s salary cap situation: "No one wants to compete and get after it more than Dez," Jones said, via the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. "At the same time, we all know this is a business where everybody has to be accountable. Certainly everybody knows that. That's a tough one. Certainly we're going to be grinding it out and trying to determine what is in the best interest of our business. "Dez understands this is a business. No one thinks more of Dez Bryant than starting at the top, Jerry, and certainly me, his teammates, coach [Jason] Garrett, Will McClay. We all have a tremendous amount of respect for Dez. That's one of the things that we're going to have to work through as we move into our future." Bryant, 29, is set to enter the fourth-year of his 5-year/$70M contract ($45M in total guarantees) and stands to make a base salary of $12.5M for the 2018 season.
In addition, Bryant is set to have a $16.5M cap hit against the team’s pay roll for the upcoming season, which has brought his future with the team in question.
Bryant started all 16 games this season and hauled in 69 receptions for 838 yards and six touchdowns.
The Cowboys can save $8.5M of cap space by trading or releasing Bryant this offseason.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Bengals VP Troy Blackburn says they will not re-do QB Andy Dalton’s current contract to increase his pay.
The quarterback market continues to evolve as Kirk Cousins received a three-year deal from the Minnesota Vikings that will pay him an annual salary of $28M. Right below him is Jimmy Garoppolo, who is set to earn a yearly salary of $27.5M with his new contract.
Dalton, 30, makes an average salary of $16M under his contract, which ranks him 21st amongst all qualified quarterbacks. Signal callers such as Arizona’s Sam Bradford ($20M), Miami’s Ryan Tannehill ($19.25M), Jacksonville’s Blake Bortles ($18M), and Denver’s Case Keenum ($18M) all make more money than Dalton over the course of their contract.
However, that will not prompt the Bengals’ to adjust his contract. “We didn’t sign the Andy Dalton deal because we thought it was a good deal. At the time it was an expensive deal. It was a heavy lift,” Blackburn said. “We did it because Andy was a winning starting quarterback in the National Football League, he had demonstrated that. We know statistically your best chance of success is by rewarding your own players and maintaining that quality core. That is what drove that. We are certainly aware quarterback deals have evolved since then. We know that at the right time we will have to evolve as well. We don’t think this is the time right now. What we are going to focus on right now is building the best team for 2018 we possibly can.” Dalton is entering the fourth year of his 6-year/$96M deal ($17M in total guarantees) and is due base salaries of $13.7M, $16M, and $17.5M over the final three years of the agreement.
Dalton started all 16 games this past season and threw for 3,320 yards, 25 touchdowns and 12 interceptions to go along with a 59.9 completion percentage.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Browns LT Joe Thomas says he will notify the team if he intends to return or retire before the start of free agency.
_______________________________________________________
“I’d like to make a decision before free agency to give the Browns the best opportunity to prepare for everything that happens in the offseason,” Thomas said on SiriusXM NFL Radio, via Pro Football Talk. “Whether I’m going to come back or retire, I think, from their perspective, having a certain need going into free agency is important.” Thomas, 33, has been contemplating retirement this offseason after he suffered torn triceps this past season. In addition, Thomas mentioned that he has been experiencing early stage memory loss, but added that it wouldn’t affect his decision to continue playing.
Thomas, a former 2007 first-round pick, is set to enter the final year of his 7-year/$80.5M contract and stands to make a base salary of $10.3M for the upcoming season.
The Browns re-worked Thomas’ contract this past November to make him the highest paid offensive lineman for the 2018 season. Cleveland gave Thomas $3M in new money over 2017 and 2018, including a $1.5M roster bonus. The Browns also added an additional $1.5M to Thomas’ 2018 base salary to make it $10.3M.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones says he plans to meet with WR Dez Bryant within the next week or so regarding his contract for the 2018 season.
Jones says he expects their conversation to be “straightforward” and “candid.” Bryant, 29, is set to enter the fourth year of his 5-year/$70M contract ($45M guaranteed) and is due a base salary of $12.5M over the final two years of the agreement. In addition, Bryant is set to carry a $16.5M cap hit.
Jones added that their signings of Allen Hurns and Deonte Thompson can make their receiving corps a strength, especially if they can work things out with Bryant. “I think that these two guys that we signed and what we might look at in the draft, at any level of the draft, plus what we might get worked out with Dez, gives us a good looking receiver outlook,” Jones said.

If both sides fail to find common ground, Dallas would free up $8.5M of cap space by releasing Bryant, while absorbing $8M of dead money.
Bryant started all 16 games this past season and caught 69 passes for 838 yards and six touchdowns.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the New Orleans Saints will not re-sign impending free-agent S Kenny Vaccaro this offseason.
It was reported last week that Vacarro was likely to test the open market, but it’s now apparent that the Saints are ready to move on from the former 2013 first-round safety.

Vaccaro, 27, says he was caught off guard after being informed of the Saints’ plans to let him walk in free agency. “It kind of frustrated me a little at first,” Vaccaro said, “but I understand it is what is.” Vaccaro mentioned that he was hoping to finish out his career in New Orleans, but knows it’s now out of his control. “I love the Saints,” Vaccaro said. “Obviously, if it was my choice, you would want to stay with the team you played your whole career with.” Vaccaro played out his 2017 fifth-year option and recorded 60 tackles, 1.5 sacks, three interceptions, a fumble recovery for a touchdown, and seven pass defenses in 12 starts this season.

NFL News: Packers impending free-agent S Morgan Burnett says he is “excited” to test the open market next month.
_______________________________________________________
“When you’ve been in a place for so long, you put your heart and soul into something going on (nine seasons), it’s going to be tough if it plays out another way,” Burnett said. “And then, at the same time, you’re excited because it’s exciting to know and a blessing to know that (there’s) other teams that are going to pursue you and other teams that might want you. That’s always a good thing, to be wanted in the NFL.” Burnett says his focus is on finding a place where he feels coveted. “It’s just about being somewhere where you’re wanted, really,” Burnett explained. “And I feel like everything else will fall into place. If a team feels like I don’t fit their scheme, I’m pretty sure they probably won’t come after me. My main goal is just wanting to be somewhere where I know a team is very interested in me and I know a team is going to be just as happy with me as I am with them. For me, it’s just all about being wanted, so whoever wants me, I’ll be happy to be there.” Burnett, 29, finished playing out his 4-year/$24.75M contract and is scheduled to become an unrestricted free-agent in March.
Burnett appeared in 12 games for the Packers this season and recorded 68 tackles, a forced fumble, and three pass defenses.

NFL News: 49ers GM John Lynch says they are “working hard” to sign QB Jimmy Garoppolo to a long-term deal.
_______________________________________________________ “He was a great addition to our team – kind of a game-changer,” Lynch said, via CSN Bay Area. “When you find the right guy at that position, it’s really good for your franchise. We believe we found the right guy.” Lynch expressed optimism about getting an extension completed this offseason: “Now the challenge is getting Jimmy signed. We’re working hard toward that. We’ll see. I think he wants to be with us, and we want him there. It makes too much sense for it not to happen. It’s just a matter of getting it done.” The 49ers acquired Garoppolo from the New England Patriots for a 2018 second-round pick before the trade deadline.
Garoppolo, 26, played out the final year of his 4-year/$3.48M rookie contract and is set to become an unrestricted free-agent in March.
Garoppolo appeared in six games this season and threw for 1,560 yards, 7 touchdowns, and 5 interceptions to go along with a 67.4 completion percentage.

The Indianapolis Colts announced Josh McDaniels as their next head coach on February 6th. That same evening, McDaniels informed Colts’ GM Chris Ballard that he was returning to New England after second thought.
McDaniels made his first public comments about the process: “I wasn’t 100 percent sure what the future was. I just hadn’t had any clarity on that,’’ McDaniels said. “So, where did I fit in? Where there any plans? I just didn’t have much clarity on what my role was here moving forward. “The opportunity to stay here and work for who I think is the greatest owner in sports and the best head football coach in the history of our game, to work with the best quarterback that has ever played . . . Look, I’m privileged to have the opportunity to do that and when they kind of crystallized that — ‘Hey, here’s what we see going forward and here’s how we would like you to fit into it’ — it gave me a reason to stop and say, ‘all right, what’s the best decision for me?’ And certainly it was difficult. But I made the decision on my own, nobody pushed me into it.’’ McDaniels says his conversation with Ballard was “as difficult a decision as I’ve ever made professionally.” “Chris was tremendous the whole entire time,’’ said McDaniels. “He’s an incredible human being. He’s great at what he does. He’s going to be successful. It was difficult. I had a friendship with him — I still do . . . He’s a guy that I have a lot of respect for and admiration for. He was a big reason why I was interested in that job in the first place. It was as difficult a decision as I’ve ever made professionally. He handled it extremely well, he was a complete professional about it.’’ McDaniels apologized to anyone impacted by his decision and praised the Colts for being a “tremendous organization.” “And I apologize to anyone who was affected in any way. Indianapolis did a tremendous job,” McDaniels said. “They have a tremendous organization and I was lucky to be considered and I just think once I found out [what my future in New England was], I made the right decision for me and my family at this time.” McDaniels, 41, will now enter his 7th season as New England’s offensive coordinator.

NFL News: 49ers GM John Lynch addressed the media regarding LB Reuben Foster’s two offseason arrests.
Here’s some of his notable comments on Foster: “We’ve made it a part of our core principles, our core values, that we’re going to be transparent,” Lynch said at the NFL Scouting Combine. “We feel like the fans deserve to know. We want them to know. With this, we’ve been a little quiet. And that’s for a reason. There are certain places I can’t and won’t go because we’re dealing with an ongoing legal matter. That’s in everyone’s best interest.” “If you remember at this time last year, there was a lot of discussion about Reuben,” Lynch said. “One thing we knew was we were going to have to put great structure around him. One lesson I learned, it’s probably a lot easier to do that in the college environment than in the NFL. These guys have to be men. We take the approach that we’re going to equip them with every resource that we can.” Lynch and HC Kyle Shanahan have spoken to Foster multiple times following his arrests of alleged domestic violence and marijuana possession. “We have talked with Reuben and the context in a broad sense of what we discussed with Reuben is just our expectations for him and our expectations for all our players,” Lynch said. “We have a high standard. We made that very clear with him. We remain in communication.” The Santa Clara County District Attorney’s office is considering whether to pursue criminal charges against Foster. He could also be subject to NFL discipline.

Foster’s uncertainty is an area of concern for the 49ers, who must consider adding a starting-caliber inside linebacker this offseason. “You have to take those things into account on every situation,” Lynch said. “Everything in this league is fluid, so you have to be able to move quickly and kind of adjust philosophies. Yeah, that will be something that we have to take into account, whether it’s in free agency, re-signing our own guys or whether it be in the draft. That’s certainly something we’re aware of and are taking into account.” ________________________________________________________

NFL News: Redskins impending free-agent QB Kirk Cousins says he was “surprised” by the Alex Smith trade, but is excited about entering free agency.
_______________________________________________________
“It was a surprise,” Cousins said, via the Washington Post. “I was actually working out at my hotel room here in Minneapolis and when I finished the workout went over and saw the news. Every player looks forward to free agency. It looks like I’m going to be a free agent on March 14. I guess there are still some dates to check off, but it should be an exciting process.” Cousins added that he believes Washington is in a “good place” with Smith: “I was keeping an open mind,” Cousins said. ” . . . I think Washington can win. I think they’re in a good place. I think they’re in a position to be successful.” The Smith trade leaves Cousins in line to be the biggest free agent on the market and says he’s looking forward to choosing where he’ll play next. “In this league and my story, I’ve learned that curveballs come all the time,” Cousins said in an interview with SiriusXM NFL Radio. “I expect to be a free agent come March 14. We’ll see if that plays out, and if it does, it’s a unique opportunity that I look forward to. I haven’t had a chance to pick where I wanted to play since 2007 when I chose to go to Michigan State.” Cousins also added that he found out about the trade on twitter and didn’t hear from the team until the next day.
Cousins, 29, threw for 4,093 yards, 27 touchdowns, and 13 interceptions to go along with a 64.3 completion percentage this season.
Cousins has accumulated a 24-23-1 record in three seasons as the Redskins’ starting quarterback. Cousins led the Redskins to the playoffs in 2015 after a 9-7 season, but they went on to lose a wildcard game to the Green Bay Packers.
Stay tuned for more.

________________________________________________________

This Just In: NFL VP Troy Vincent confirmed that the league will change the controversial catch rule.
According to Mark Maske of the Washington Post, Vincent said the NFL plans to eliminate two factors that can cause incompletions. "Slight movement of the ball, it looks like we'll reverse that," he said. "Going to the ground, it looks like that's going to be eliminated. And we'll go back to the old replay standard of reverse the call on the field only when it's indisputable." Vincent added that the competition committee is looking to finalize its proposal today before presenting it at next week’s league meeting in Orlando, Florida.
Vincent mentioned two infamous non-catches in recent years and reiterated that they would be catches under their proposed rule change: "The Dez Bryant play, that'd be a catch. The Jesse James play, that'd be a catch." After several years of uncertainty regarding the catch rule, it appears change is coming starting in the 2018 season.

NFL News: According to reports, Redskins impending free-agent QB Kirk Cousins and his representatives will file a grievance against the team if they franchise tag him with the intention of trading him to another team.
Cousins and his reps would “quickly” file a grievance to block the franchise tag, given that the Redskins would be violating the spirit of the rules.
The franchise tag rules dictate that players can be tagged as a placeholder for teams to buy time toward getting a long-term deal finalized.
The Redskins’ agreed trade to acquire QB Alex Smith reveals that they do not plan to use their franchise tag with the proper intent, which could prompt the NFL to rule in favor of Cousins if this particular situation occurs.
Cousins, 29, played out his one-year/$23.943M franchise tender this season and is scheduled to become an unrestricted free-agent in March.

NFL News: Browns GM John Dorsey says he supports WR Josh Gordon and mentioned that he’s been in frequent contact with him throughout the offseason.
_______________________________________________________ “I think Josh Gordon is a physical freak,” Dorsey said in the interview, as partially transcribed by Nate Ulrich of the Akron Beacon Journal. “I’ve sat down and talked to him, had numerous conversations, and my message to Josh Gordon is, ‘You know what? As long as you’re behind the Cleveland Browns 100 percent, I’m 100 percent behind Josh Gordon.’ “That’s my mindset. He and I have communicated, and there’s some things that I’ve helped him with and we’ve sat and discussed. But right now, I love where he is right now. I think he’s in a good place right now, but we’ll see how this thing moves forward.” The NFL Players Association initially claimed that Gordon was a restricted free-agent, but later backtracked on their statement following clarity from the league office.
Gordon, 26, is indeed listed as an exclusive rights free-agent this offseason, which practically means he’s not going anywhere.
All the Browns have to do is offer him a one-year contract for the minimum salary to retain his rights for the 2018 season and it’s something they certainly do in the coming weeks.
Gordon will then become a restricted free-agent in 2019, which means the Browns will have the option to place a first, second, or an original-round tender on him.
Gordon was selected in the 2012 NFL supplemental draft, but had his contract tolled for the 2014 and 2015 seasons due to suspensions.
Gordon was reinstated by the NFL on November 1st of last year and made his first game appearance in nearly three years vs. Chargers in Week 13. Gordon ended up starting the final five games of the 2017 season and caught 18 passes for 335 yards and one touchdown.
As the Browns now prepare for the 2018 season, Gordon appears to be firmly involved in their plans moving forward.

NFL News: Giants WR Odell Beckham Jr. says he wants to finalize a long-term contract extension in the near future.
_______________________________________________________ "Hopefully to get it done," Beckham said of his mindset about the contract issue Saturday, per NJ.com. "It's that time just to get it over with. I really want to do it so I can move past it. "It's too much sitting around thinking, 'Where am I going to be at?' I need to know where I can start buying furniture for a house. I want to have a place set where I know, 'OK, this is home. I can always go back to home.' So it's just a little intermediate process right now. I'm sure it will get worked out." Giants co-owner John Mara said last week the team would "get something done.” Beckham said he has already met with new GM Dave Gettleman and was encouraged with his vision for the team: "It was great," Beckham said of his first meeting with Gettleman. "He seems like a straight-shooter. We only met once, but from the conversation you can kind of have an understanding of who a person is. It seems like this is going to be a very fun year." Beckham, 25, played out the final year of his 4-year/$10.4M rookie contract and stands to make a base salary of $8.45M under his 2018 fifth-year option.
Beckham appeared in four games this season and recorded 25 receptions for 302 yards and three touchdowns before suffering a season-ending ankle injury.

Stay tuned for more.
