UPDATE: Giants owner John Mara says they are not inclined to trade WR Odell Beckham Jr. following his recent behavior, but have not ruled out the possibility of doing so.
Here’s what Mara had to say when asked about potentially trading Beckham: “I can’t answer that one way or another,” Mara told reporters, including Ralph Vacchiano of SNY. “We’re certainly not shopping him if that’s what you’re asking. But again, when you’re coming off a season where you’re 3-13 and played as poorly as we played, I wouldn’t say that anybody is untouchable. “You always listen to those things,” Mara said. “But that’s not a scenario that I would like to see happen. I’m tired of answering questions about Odell’s behavior and what the latest incident is. I think he knows what we expect of him. Now it’s up to him.” A video surfaced earlier this month showing Beckham laying down holding a thick brown cigarette in his left hand and a pizza box on top of bed sheets.
As the camera panned, a woman is seen holding a credit card in front of what looks to be a white substance.
The Giants were made aware of the video and are reportedly “irked” and “frustrated” with Beckham’s latest stirrups.
The questionable video surfaced during an offseason where Beckham is looking to become the highest paid wide receiver and it certainly hasn’t help his cause.

The Giants are at the point where they are considering the possibility of letting him play out the 2018 season without a long-term deal in place.
Beckham, 25, is due to make a base salary of $8.459M under his fifth-year option and could potentially hit the open market next offseason if the Giants choose to part ways with him.
Beckham appeared in four games this past season (2 starts) and caught 25 passes for 302 yards and three touchdowns before suffering a fractured left ankle in Week 5 vs. Chargers.

Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, RB Matt Forte and WR/KR Devin Hester will sign one-day contracts with the Chicago Bears on Monday to officially retire as members of the team.
Forte, 32, is a former second-round pick of the Bears back in 2008. He spent eight years in Chicago before signing a three-year, $12M contract with the Jets in 2016.

For his career, Forte rushed for 9,796 yards on 2,356 carries (4.2 YPC) to go along with 554 receptions and 4,672 yards receiving and 89 total touchdowns over the course of 10 seasons and 146 games.

Forte was a two-time Pro Bowl selection.

Hester, 35, is a former second-round pick of the Bears back in 2006. After eight years with the Bears, Hester signed a three-year, $9M contract with Atlanta and was set to make a base salary of $3.5M for the 2016 season when the Falcons released him during the offseason.

For his career, Hester totaled 3,695 punt return yards, 7,333 kick return yards and 19 total return touchdowns over the course of 11 years in the NFL. He also caught 255 passes for 3,311 yards receiving and 16 touchdowns.

NFL News: According to reports, Several teams are planning to contact the New England Patriots regarding TE Rob Gronkowski’s availability for a trade.

Gronkowski, 28, is set to enter the fifth year of his 6-year/$54M deal and stands to make base salaries of $8M and $9M over the final two years of the agreement.

NFL News: Lions HC Matt Patricia confirmed that he will not be the primary defensive play-caller for the upcoming season.
Patricia has called defensive plays for the last eight years in New England, but he will cede those duties to his defensive coordinator in Detroit. “Coach Pasqualoni will be calling the defense, and he’ll be running it from that standpoint,” Patricia said this week. “In general, I’ll call whatever I need to offensively, defensively or special teams. But yeah, he’ll be in charge.” Paul Pasqualoni, 68, most recently served as the defensive line coach at Boston College for the last two years and served as an NFL defensive coordinator from 2008-2010.

NFL News: According to reports, the New York Jets are preparing to make a “big run” at signing impending free-agent QB Kirk Cousins this offseason.
The Jets are an intriguing landing spot for Cousins because of their recently promoted OC Jeremy Bates. Bates is a product of Mike Shanahan’s boot-action offense, as are Former Redskins offensive coordinators, Rams HC Sean McVay and 49ers HC Kyle Shanahan.
Bates served as an offensive assistant and quarterbacks coach under Shanahan during his head coaching tenure with the Denver Broncos and learned the boot-action offense firsthand. That is an offensive system Cousins thrived in with the Redskins and has been vocal about Bates’ familiarity with the scheme. “Shanahan and McVay are great football minds and I’ve been very fortunate to have one good coach after another,” Cousins told New York’s WFAN on Tuesday. “Jeremy Bates does come from that coaching tree, if you will.” Cousins then went on to commend the Jets for making a “smart” move by promoting Bates to offensive coordinator.
The Jets will hope to use Bates’ connection with Cousins to their benefit as they get ready to court him hard when free agency officially opens in mid-March.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Giants WR Odell Beckham Jr. plans to hold out for a new contract.
Beckham has informed Giants’ team officials that he will not step foot on a field unless he has a long-term contract in place for the upcoming 2018 season.
This development comes one day after Giants owner John Mara said no player is “untouchable” in trade talks.
Beckham, 25, is due to make a base salary of $8.459M under his fifth-year option and has made his desire clear to become the highest paid wide receiver in the league.

NFL News: According to reports, Patriots TE Rob Gronkowski physically and mentally battled through the 2017 season and “did not enjoy” the process.
New reports continue to surface since Gronkowski hinted at retirement following the Patriots’ Super Bowl 52 loss to the Eagles.
Tom E. Curran of NBC Sports Boston says Gronkowski “did not enjoy himself” this past season and mentioned that he butted heads with the Patriots’ coaching staff during training camp. Gronkowski was reportedly not happy with the structure of training camp and believed the players should have gotten more rest in between padded practices. Gronkowski’s discontent with the situation nearly prompted him to step away from the team.
Curran added that Gronkowski is physically and mentally drained and is legitimately considering the possibility of stepping away from the game.
The WWE has expressed interest in signing Gronkowski, should he follow through with retirement this offseason. In addition, many top Hollywood film producers have reached out to Gronkowski to gauge his interest in pursuing an acting career.
While no firm decision is expected anytime soon, the Patriots may have to start preparing to be without their 5X Pro Bowl tight end for the upcoming season.
Gronkowski, 28, is set to enter the fifth year of his 6-year/$54M contract and is due to make base salaries of $8M and $9M for the 2018 and 2019 seasons.
Gronkowski started 14 regular season games for the Patriots and hauled in 69 receptions for 1,084 yards, and eight touchdowns.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the New York Jets are “split” as to how they view Oklahoma QB Baker Mayfield and UCLA QB Josh Rosen.
If USC QB Sam Darnold remains available to the Jets at No. 3 overall, he would reportedly be the “overwhelming favorite” to be the pick. There is a general consensus within their organization that Darnold is the top quarterback of this year’s class, which is why they brought him in for an official Top-30 visit.
However, they know the chances of him falling to them are slim, so they have focused their discussions on Mayfield and Rosen. It’s worth noting that Wyoming QB Josh Allen would be considered if he remained available to them, but there is growing belief that he’ll go No. 1 overall to the Cleveland Browns.
Jets GM Mike Maccagnan was a Mayfield skeptic earlier in the pre-draft process, which gave Rosen the early head-to-head advantage between the two. Maccagnan’s primary concern with Mayfield was how he would handle the New York market, but that worry quickly diminished after their official pre-draft visit with the 2017 Heisman winner.
Brian Costello of the New York Post describes a “hearty debate” among the Jets’ brass about the merits of Rosen and Mayfield and what they bring to the table. There is reportedly a 50/50 split on both prospects within their organization, as some team executives believe Rosen is the most pro-ready passer in this draft.
With just four days left until the start of the 2018 NFL Draft, the Jets have not been able to agree on which signal caller is the best fit for their franchise and only time will tell who’ll win their internal debate.
Stay tuned for more.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the Pittsburgh Steelers, Cleveland Browns, Philadelphia Eagles, and Los Angeles Chargers are scheduled to host Australian Rugby player Jordan Mailata for a visit this week.

Mailata, who stands 6’8”, 346lbs, made a strong impression on NFL scouts during his workout last weekend in Florida by posting impressive numbers.
He ran a 5.12-second 40-yard dash, which would have been the seventh fastest time among tackle participants at the scouting combine. Mailata is currently working out at IMG Academy in Bradenton, Florida, under Aden Durde, the same coach that trained Former Vikings WR Moritz Böhringer during the pre-draft process.
Mailata is eligible to be selected in the upcoming NFL Draft and is hoping to hear his name called before the event comes to an end later this month.

NFL News: Tom Brady’s agent, Don Yee, confirmed that his client will return for the 2018 season, despite recent reports stating otherwise. “Tom’s intentions have not changed,” Yee said Monday. “He’s consistently said he’ll play beyond this contract and into his mid 40s, or until he feels he isn’t playing at a championship level. I understand the constant speculation, but this is one point he’s been firm about.” Yee added says Brady is still training every day in preparation for the upcoming season. “He customizes his preparation to each season in order to maximize his performance,” Yee said. “His training methods are always evolving and getting better. The year he missed the first four games — that month of training on his own was particularly efficient.” Regarding his contract, Yee said: “His objective every year is to outperform his contract and his own goals. And like every player, yes, he thinks about his contract — it’s a pretty natural thing to do. Every team’s management knows this.” Brady, 40, is a former sixth-round pick of the Patriots back in 2000. He signed a 2-year/$41M contract extension with the Patriots back in 2016, which included a $28M signing bonus. Brady stands to make a base salary of $15M in both the 2018 and 2019 seasons.
In 2017, Brady started all 16 games for the Patriots and threw for 4,577 yards while completing 66.3 percent of his passes to go along with 32 touchdowns and eight interceptions.
In three playoff starts, Brady accumulated 1,132 pass yards, eight touchdowns and zero interceptions to go along with a 64.0 completion percentage.
Stay tuned for more.

The Eagles received an excellent haul of draft compensation when they traded QB Sam Bradford to the Minnesota Vikings, in which they acquired a 2017 first-round pick to go along with a 2018 fourth-round pick.
Fast forward two years, and the Eagles appear to be using that very deal as leverage to receive an adequate amount of draft capital.
The Eagles have informed all interested teams that they’ll have to fork up at least a first and a fourth-round pick for their offer to receive consideration. Philadelphia views Foles as the best insurance policy in the NFL and are not willing to give him up easily.
It was reported on Monday that an AFC team had offered a 2018 second-round pick for Foles, but that deal is certainly not close to what the Eagles are seeking at the moment.
Foles started three regular season games and threw for 537 yards, five touchdowns, and two interceptions to go along with a 56.4 completion percentage.
In his three playoff starts, Foles accumulated 971 yards passing, six touchdowns, and one interception to go along with a 72.6 completion percentage.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Former Packers CB Sam Shields says he wants to play in the 2018 season, despite sitting out the last two years with concussion-related issues.
Shields reiterated his excitement to return to football and is confident that he’ll land with a team this offseason: “It’s going to feel great,” Shields said of his recovery. “You’re going to see the (number) 37 you remembered. Everything you seen in Green Bay, you’re going to see that wherever I’m at.” Shields says he believes he’s back to his normal self after dealing with serious concussion-related issues the past few years. “I think I’m back to my normal self,” Shields said. “I can just take one day at a time and try to keep conditioning to get myself ready for whatever, March or April, whatever team picks me up so I can be ready to go.” Shields thinks there’s a chance the Packers could re-sign him this offseason: “That I really don’t know. But shoot, as I see on my social media, man, they still love me. That’s always been there, especially with the Packers since I’ve been there. It’s always been love. Not just me, but anybody. That’s just the love we’ve got from the fans,” Shields said. “But yeah, I think they would (bring me back).” Shields, 30, signed with the Packers as an undrafted free-agent In 2010 and spent six seasons in Green Bay, before being released in 2016.

NFL News: Patriots CB Malcolm Butler says the team’s coaching staff “gave up” on him in the wake of his Super Bowl benching.
_______________________________________________________ “They gave up on me. F—. It is what it is,” Butler Mike Reiss of ESPN.com. “I don’t know what it was. I guess I wasn’t playing good or they didn’t feel comfortable. I don’t know. But I could have changed that game.” HC Bill Belichick made the surprising decision to bench Butler for today’s game vs. Eagles and opted to start Eric Rowe in his place.
When asked about why he chose to sit Butler for the entire game, Belichick said it was solely a “football decision.” The Patriots elected to use Rowe and Johnson Bademosi, a primary special-teamer, to replace Butler in three corner sets.
Butler, an impending free-agent, had expressed his desire to re-sign with the Patriots earlier this week, but all signs indicate that he’s ready to move on after being snubbed of a Super Bowl start.
It is worth noting that Butler played the most defensive snaps in the regular season.

NFL News: Cardinals GM Steve Keim is noncommittal about exercising S Tyrann Mathieu’s 2018 contract option.

Mathieu is set to enter the second year of his 5-year/$62.5M contract he signed in August of 2016 and is scheduled to have a $14.1M cap hit for the upcoming season.
The Cardinals would save $4.8M of cap space by trading or releasing Mathieu ahead of the new league year, while absorbing $9.3M of dead money. The Cardinals could approach Mathieu about taking a potential pay cut or they could look to part ways with the dynamic safety if both sides fail to find common ground.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the New Orleans Saints hosted Louisville QB Lamar Jackson for a Top-30 visit on Tuesday.
This is not the only meeting between the two, as Saints OC Pete Carmichael and QBs coach Joe Lombardi attended Louisville’s pro day to watch Jackson throw a couple weeks ago.
While Drew Brees, 39, is back in the fold for the 2018 season, the Saints need to identify his future successor.
Saints HC Sean Payton appears to be a fan of Jackson, as he called him a “special” player. “I like him. I like him. He’s athletic. He’s got a magic smile to him. He’s a leader,” head coach Sean Payton recently said. “With Lamar, you feel it in the room, and you can tell he can lead. … He’s a special guy. You just have to be around him, interview him, and you can see why he was successful.” Jackson offers a completely different skill set than Brees, but that doesn’t seem to alter Payton’s interest in him. “The trick for a team that takes a quarterback at any point to become or to compete to become a starter, one of our jobs is to look closely at what are the things that player does best,” Payton said. “If he’s your quarterback, you start looking closely at what he did well at Louisville, and you build that way. We’re never wanting to just take any of these players … and enter the game and view them just as Drew entered the game. They’re different athletes.” The Saints currently hold the 27th overall pick of the draft.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the New York Jets believe Redskins impending free-agent QB Kirk Cousins is destined to sign with the Minnesota Vikings.
The Jets still plan to aggressively pursue Cousins and will likely be the highest bidder by a wide margin, but they are concerned that it won’t be enough to lure him their way.
Many executives within the Jets’ organization feel like their chances of signing him significantly dwindled when the Vikings entered the mix. The Jets ultimately believe the Vikings’ readiness to win now will sway Cousins to Minnesota, despite their willingness to “throw a truckload of money and a heavily front-loaded contract” his way.
Cousins is believed to be seeking a 3-year contract worth $90M in free agency and the Jets will make every effort to meet his asking price. However, the Jets have already started prepping their plan B and plan C, should they swing and miss on Cousins.
The Denver Broncos and Arizona Cardinals are the two other finalists to sign Cousins.

Cousins, 29, threw for 4,093 yards, 27 touchdowns, and 13 interceptions to go along with a 64.3 completion percentage in 16 starts this season.

NFL News: Cowboys VP Stephen Jones admitted that WR Dez Bryant’s sideline demeanor can be a distraction for the team.
_______________________________________________________ “The other thing that we all see and it is certainly visible to anyone who watches our games, watches our sideline, is Dez is certainly a fiery guy who plays with a lot of emotion both on and off the field,” Jones said on the Cowboys’ Hangin’ With The Boys podcast, via the Dallas Morning News. “Sometimes that can be a distraction. It can be a distraction for Dez, it can be a distraction for other teammates. And we just have to really get our hands around when you put all the full body of work together where that’s headed.” As the offseason gets underway, there has been a lot of speculation regarding Bryant’s future in Dallas. Jones’ comments here certainly make the situation much more interesting.
Bryant’s production has significantly diminished in the Cowboys’ offense and it has led many team executives to consider be possibility of releasing him. However, owner Jerry Jones has voiced his support of Bryant and reiterated that he will return for the 2018 season.
Bryant finished the 2017 season with 69 receptions, 838 receiving yards, and 6 touchdowns, but has not posted a 1,000 yard season since 2014.
Bryant, 29, is set to enter the fourth year of his 5-year/$70M contract and stands to make a base salary of $12.5M for the 2018 season.
When asked about the possibility of accepting a pay cut to remain with the Cowboys last month, Bryant scoffed at the idea and said he believes in his ability to make good on his deal.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Cowboys DE Randy Gregory is in the process of filing for reinstatement from the NFL.
Gregory, a former 2015 second-round pick, has only played in 14 career games since entering the league.
Gregory, 25, missed four games during his rookie season due to a high-ankle sprain, but still managed to appear in 12 games.
However, Gregory’s troubles began in 2016 when he was suspended a total of 14 games for violating the league’s substance abuse policy twice. In result, Gregory played in the team’s final two regular season games before being suspended for an entire year following a third failed drug test.
Gregory missed the entire 2017 season due to suspension, but it appears he is making an attempt to regain eligibility for the upcoming 2018 season.
Gregory has spent time at multiple drug rehab centers and is reportedly in good physical and mental shape.
While his chance for reinstatement is far from guaranteed, Gregory is certainly looking into the matter and is hoping to get another opportunity to play.
It’s worth noting that the last two years have not counted as accrued seasons toward Gregory’s free-agent status. With that being said, the Cowboys will have him under contract through 2020 if he is granted reinstatement.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, the Cincinnati Bengals did not offer free-agent S Eric Reid a contract during his visit on Monday.
Bengals owner Mike Brown reportedly met with Reid during his visit on Monday and questioned him about his decision to kneel during the national anthem.

Mike Florio of ProFootballTalk says Brown explained that he intends to prohibit this and asked for Reid’s response.

Reid was reportedly caught off guard by the line of questioning and wasn’t willing to make a commitment on the spot, even though he said last month that he was no longer planning to kneel during the anthem.

The Bengals had Reid take a physical and watch tape with members of the coaching staff, who reportedly were interested in signing him regardless if he’d kneel during the anthem.

Interestingly enough, Florio adds that Bengals HC Marvin Lewis asked Reid if he wants to clarify anything that Reid told ownership regarding the anthem, but Reid said he had nothing to clarify or change about what he told Brown.

Reid’s visit with the Bengals wrapped up without an offer being made.

The San Francisco 49ers offered Reid a one-year deal to return, but Reid declined stating that he wanted “long-term security”. That was something the 49ers were unwilling to commit to Reid, considering their position to draft another safety in the upcoming NFL Draft.
Reid, 26, started 12 games for the 49ers this past season and recorded 67 combined tackles, two interceptions, four pass defenses, and one fumble recovery.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, Packers QB Aaron Rodgers is “frustrated” due to the team failing to include him in key decisions.
Rodgers wants to be included in the decision-making process in terms of the roster moves being made by management, especially given that some of the moves directly impact him.

Rodgers is both “frustrated” and “emotional” because he was not consulted before the Packers made some significant personnel changes this offseason.

The two moves in particular that irked Rodgers were the departures of WR Jordy Nelson and QBs coach Alex Van Pelt. “Both of those decisions [with Nelson and Van Pelt] were made without him,” a league source close said. “In both situations, he had no influence with [the front office] before anything went down.” “I know he’s thinking about that stuff when it comes to the next contract because he should have earned a voice by now. In other places with [elite] quarterbacks, consideration is given to those guys. I think Aaron wants to be engaged in some decisions. But that’s just not the way it works [in Green Bay]. I think that’s obviously frustrating and it’s going to keep coming out.” The expectation has been that the Packers and Rodgers would get a long-term extension finalized this offseason, but their contract talks have gone stagnant.

Rodgers, 34, is entering the sixth year of his 7-year/$130.75M contract and stands to make base salaries of $19.8M and $20M over the final two years of the agreement.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: DeAngelo Hall says the Redskins never received commitment from QB Kirk Cousins. “We kind of felt like the commitment wasn’t there from Kirk,” Hall said Tuesday on “SportsCenter” in the first of his multiple appearances as a guest analyst during a visit to ESPN headquarters. “We obviously wanted Kirk. We franchised him because we wanted him there. It was up to ownership and the front office to kind of work those numbers out. They couldn’t get the numbers worked out, so he signed franchise tags those two football seasons. Everybody in that locker room was behind Kirk, wanted him there, but we wanted to feel like he wanted to be there as well. Having played 14 years, I understand, ‘Let’s go get the money,’ but at some point there has to be mutual interest from both parties to want to get better collectively as a team. Paying Kirk probably the $30 million he’s going to get, we couldn’t do that and get better as a football team.” _______________________________________________________
In three seasons, Cousins accumulated a 24-23-1 record as the Redskins’ starting quarterback. During his tenure in Washington, Cousins led the team to the playoffs in 2015, where they lost to the Green Bay Packers in the wildcard round.
Cousins, 29, will become an unrestricted free agent after playing under the franchise tag the last two seasons.
Cousins started all 16 games for the Redskins in 2017 and threw for 4,093 yards, 27 touchdowns, and 13 interceptions to go along with a 64.3 completion percentage.

NFL News: Eagles HC Doug Pederson expects LT Jason Peters to remain in Philadelphia for the 2018 season.
There has been a lot of talk about the Eagles potentially releasing Peters to create cap space this offseason, but that doesn’t appear to be the plan at the moment according to Pederson: “This guy is a Pro Bowl left tackle,” Pederson said (via Matt Lombardo of NJ.com). “Guys like that, in my humble opinion, they can go out whenever they want to go out. I respect him, and what he’s done, and how he’s working right now through injury. If you had to hold a gun to my head right now, I’d say ‘yeah, he’s my left tackle.’” Peters, 36, is set to enter the second year of his 3-year/$27.75M deal and stands to make a base salary of $7.75M for the 2018 season.
Peters appeared in 7 games this season before tearing his ACL and MCL in late October vs. Redskins.

UPDATE: According to reports, the Seattle Seahawks are unlikely to trade S Earl Thomas during the upcoming NFL Draft.
While rumors linking Thomas to the Dallas Cowboys continue to swirl leading up to the draft, it doesn’t appear a trade is likely at this time.
Recent reports have indicated that the Cowboys would be willing to offer their 2018 second-round pick (No. 50 overall) in exchange for the All-Pro safety, but that is no where close to the Seahawks’ current asking price.
Seattle is still believed to be seeking at least a first-round pick in any trade involving Thomas and that is the primary reason as to why they haven’t generated any interest from teams.
While it’s entirely possible that GM John Schneider could lower his asking price once the draft gets underway, it’s not something the Seahawks feel obligated to do.
Thomas’ representatives informed Schneider last week that their client will not holdout for a new deal, which has eased the growing tension between both parties.
In addition, the Cowboys are reportedly more inclined to hold off their pursuit of Thomas until next offseason, when he hits the open market as an unrestricted free-agent.
Thomas, 28, is entering the final year of his 5-year/$44.725M contract and stands to make a base salary of $8.5 million for the 2018 season.

The Seahawks would free up $8.5M of cap space by trading Thomas, while absorbing 1.9M in dead money.

In 2017, Thomas started 14 games for the Seahawks this past season and recorded 88 tackles, two interceptions with one being returned for a touchdown, a forced fumble and seven pass defenses.

UPDATE: According to reports, the New York Giants could look to trade OT Ereck Flowers during the NFL Draft.

With his 2019 fifth-year option looming, the Giants may look to trade Flowers during the upcoming draft for a late-round pick.
As mentioned before, members of the Giants’ coaching staff do not believe Flowers is fully committed to football and would prefer to move on without him.
Flowers’ bad reputation developed when he did not report for the first day of OTAs last week and was the only no-show at the Giants’ training facility. Coaches were not informed of his plan to miss the start of offseason workouts, which rubbed many within the organization the wrong way.
Exercising Flowers’ fifth-year option would cost the Giants $12.525M in 2019. With that being said, they are not planning to pick it up before May 2nd’s deadline.

NFL News: According to reports, the Cleveland Browns have requested a private visit with Oklahoma QB Baker Mayfield.
This is the first official meeting request Mayfield has received in the draft process.
The Browns plan to put him through a private workout in Southern California prior to his Pro Day at Oklahoma, which is scheduled for March 14th in Norman.
Browns GM John Dorsey defended Mayfield’s character at the Senior Bowl and mentioned that they plan to do extensive work on him leading up to the NFL Draft.
It is worth noting that the Browns recently hired Scot McCloughan as a senior personnel consultant and he previously compared Mayfield to Brett Favre: “I was lucky enough to have been around Favre, and I’ve gotten to know Baker pretty well just by watching him,” McCloughan said in an interview with “The Doug Gottlieb Show.” “There’s some off-field stuff, but nothing too hairy. I mean it happens. College kids are college kids. It’s not like he’s doing anything really bad. But he is a competitive guy. He wears it on his sleeve from the standpoint of emotions.” “He plays with strength throughout his body, and the fact that he’s just a football player — it’s impressive. It’s a really good class this year coming out in the draft for quarterbacks. But I know this, if I was going to play one game tomorrow, he’d be my guy — hands down.” It appears the Browns have one executive that is sold on Mayfield and it’ll be interesting to see how many others buy in.
The Browns currently own the No. 1 and No. 4 overall picks of the upcoming draft.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the New York Giants are “unlikely” to trade WR Odell Beckham Jr., despite other conflicting reports.
Pat Leonard of the New York Daily News reported that the Giants had discussed a potential trade with the Los Angeles Rams involving Beckham.
However, those reports have no validity at this time, despite Giants co-owner John Mara’s recent comments indicating that Beckham isn’t “untouchable”. Giants VP Steve Tisch said that they have opened preliminary contract talks with Beckham’s agent and reiterated their desire to retain him on a long-term deal. Although no significant progress has been made in negotiations, team officials are at least laying the groundwork to potentially get a deal completed ahead of the 2018 regular season.
Beckham, 25, has reportedly threatened to hold out if he doesn’t receive long-term security before Week 1 of the regular season, which has prompted Giants’ officials to reevaluate their approach with the 3X Pro-Bowler.
Beckham is seeking a base salary worth $20M per year in his next deal, so it’ll be interesting to see how he and his agent handle contract negotiations moving forward.
Giants HC Pat Shurmur says he expects Beckham to attend OTA’s next month, despite reports of a holdout.
While there is a lot more to evolve from now until training camp, the Giants appear committed to Beckham even in the wake of his offseason behavior.
Beckham is due to make a base salary of $8.459M under his 2018 fifth-year option.

Injury Update: Cowboys LT Tyron Smith says his lingering back injury and other problematic issues are now “feeling great” following a series of treatments.
_______________________________________________________
“I’m feeling great now,” Smith said, via DallasCowboys.com. “Actually, I feel like I’m in the best shape I’ve been in a while. I’ve taken this offseason to get back into it a little early and try to take care of my body a little more. I’m just doing the little small [rehab] things and I just feel awesome right now.” Smith added that he took a trip to California to get a head start with his offseason rehab: “I went to California and went to a facility out there and starting training and rehabbing a little early,” Smith added. “We just worked on the little things like stretching and taking pressure off my back and opening up my hips a little bit. It’s just little things but I’m feeling great.” Smith, 27, missed three games this past season due to back and groin injuries.
Smith, a former 2011 first-round pick (9th overall), is entering the third year of his 8-year/$97.6M deal and stands to make a base salary of $10M for the 2018 season.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the New England Patriots have strong interest in Oklahoma QB Baker Mayfield.
Tom Brady, 40, will be returning for his 19th NFL season and isn’t showing any signs of slowing down. However, the Patriots know they need to identify Brady’s heir in the immediate future and will almost certainly select a quarterback in the upcoming NFL Draft.
Patriots owner Robert Kraft alluded to the idea and says finding a quarterback is an “obvious” need. "I'm going to put my fan hat on, and obviously at some point we have to,"Kraft said, via ESPN's Mike Reiss. "Not just that, but think what happened in the '08 season when in the first quarter against Kansas City, Tom [Brady] goes out. How many people would have said that Matt Cassel would have led us to an 11-5 season? I put my faith and confidence in Bill [Belichick]. He knows his responsibilities. Anything can happen, even if Tom comes in [and is in] tip-top shape.” The Patriots acquired a 2018 first-round pick (No. 23 overall) from the Los Angeles Rams in exchange for WR Brandin Cooks on Tuesday. This now gives them a bevy of premium picks to use for a potential trade up scenario, should an opportunity present itself.
There is growing buzz from around the league that Mayfield is on the Patriots’ radar, although their chances of landing him remain slim. Word of the Patriots’ interest in Mayfield is spreading so quickly that the New York Jets and other teams picking inside the top-5 are now aware of the news.
The Patriots are set to enter this year’s draft with five picks in the top 100, with four of those being in the top two rounds: No. 23, No. 31, No. 43, No. 63, and No. 95. Even at that, they probably still don’t have the necessary ammo to make the leap into the top-5, but their search for a signal caller has been well documented and they’ll certainly explore all options come draft night.

NFL News: Cowboys RT La’el Collins says he would prefer to continue playing right tackle.
_______________________________________________________
“I like playing tackle, so hey, I think that’s where we’ll be.” However, Collins said he would be open to moving back to left guard if it benefits the team: “Man, at the end of the day, I’m here to help the football team,” Collins said. “I think we’re in the right direction. I think we’ll be where we need to be.” Collins also spoke about his first year at tackle in 2017 and how it made him a better player: “I played against a lot of great players in my first year at right tackle,” Collins said. “For me, it only made me better as a player. Honestly, I never thought I could play multiple positions at the offensive line spot. Just being able to have played pretty much every position except center, it feels great. Going against those guys last year was a big stepping stone for me going into next year.” The Cowboys inked Former Patriots OT Cameron Fleming to a one-year deal and it has given the team options with how they want to construct their starting offensive line.
Cowboys VP Stephen Jones mentioned on several occasions that they will start “the best five” offensive lineman, which could result in Fleming taking over at right tackle and Collins kicking back inside to left guard.
While no firm decision has been made, Collins is certainly hoping to stay at tackle as he enters year two at the position.

Collins, 24, started all 16 games at right tackle for the Cowboys this past season.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Texans TE C.J. Fiedorowicz says he is considering walking away from football due to his frequent history of concussions.
_______________________________________________________ “A dude knocked me out,” Fiedorowicz said his first concussion in Week 1, via Joe Stevenson of the Northwest (Ill.) Herald. “After eight weeks, when I came back, it was constantly on my mind. I wasn’t always able to play loose and free. It was in my head. Anytime that’s on your mind while you’re playing an NFL football game, you’re in trouble. You can’t play timid. Guys are trying to take your head off, you know?” Fiedorowicz has not made a firm decision yet and plans to see how he feels this offseason: “You can’t go repair your brain,” Fiedorowicz said. “It’s not like an ACL or shoulder. That’s serious. I took some dingers. There was a couple of weeks there where I was having some tough times. This is what I’ve done my whole life, so to think that I’m going to walk away is tough. It’s not something that I thought of doing, because I signed the new deal, anytime soon. Life goes on, whatever happens.” “I know I enjoy working out enough to be able to continue playing, but maybe I just need a little time away,” Fiedorowicz added. “I don’t have to make that decision right now.” Fiedorowicz, 26, signed a three-year/$21.5M contract extension with the Texans last April and is under contract through the 2020 season.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Bills impending free-agent LB Preston Brown says he is interested in a potential return to Buffalo for the 2018 season.

So hopefully they think it was a good fit as well. I don’t really know how things are gonna go. DEVELOPING: According to reports, Cowboys DL David Irving is being investigated by police for domestic violence allegations made by his ex-girlfriend.

Jobin Panicker of WFAA-ABC Dallas adds that the allegations made against Irving were reported to police on April 22nd at two separate times — 5pm and 10pm — by his ex-girlfriend.

As of now, no arrests have been made, but it appears as though recent social media posts are being taken very seriously.

Irving’s ex-girlfriend apparently “hacked” his Twitter account and posted a number of allegations against him including that he beat her, and has smoked weed and done other illegal drugs while in the NFL’s substance abuse program, via the Dallas Morning News.

Irving later responded saying that he kicked her out for cheating on him and he has since changed the locks in his house and and all of his passwords.

Dallas used a second-round restricted tender on Irving a few months ago, which will cost them $2.914 million for the 2018 season.

In 2017, Irving, 24, appeared in eight games and recorded 22 tackles, seven sacks, a forced fumble and six pass defenses.

Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the Denver Broncos have not decided if they will pick up OLB Shane Ray’s 2019 fifth-year option.
Broncos GM John Elway was recently asked what their plans were regarding Ray’s fifth-year option and he mentioned that they still hadn’t come to a definite decision.
Ray, a former 2015 first-round pick (No. 23 overall), says he isn’t too concerned about his future and is optimistic that his option will be picked up. “I’m not concerned. I love being a Bronco,” Ray said, per Nicki Jhabvala. “John’s got a lot of things to deal with, and whether or not he picks up my option, it doesn’t say anything about what I’m going to be for this team, my role for this team. I’m just excited. I wouldn’t look into too much. I think that it’s going to get picked up. I think that I’m going to be here and I’m just looking forward to this opportunity.” Ray, 24, is entering the final year of his 4-year/$9.118M rookie contract and stands to make a base salary of $1.678M in 2018. Exercising his fifth-year option would cost the Broncos $9.232M In 2019.
Ray has appeared in 38 career games over the last three seasons (15 starts) and has accumulated 84 total tackles, 13 sacks, one forced fumble, two fumble recoveries with one of them being returned for a touchdown and one pass defense.
It was revealed that Ray had suffered a torn ligament in his wrist during offseason training last July, which sidelined him for 6-8 weeks. The Broncos placed Ray on the Injured Reserve to start the 2017 season, but later activated him in Week 8. However, Denver re-placed Ray on season-ending I.R. in mid-December after he underwent a third wrist surgery.

Ray was limited to eight game appearances this past season (7 starts) and finished with 16 total tackles and one sack.
The deadline to pick up Ray’s fifth-year option is May 2nd.

NFL News: Patriots WR Malcolm Mitchell says missing the entire 2017 season was an “adverse situation”, but added that he is refueled and ready for the upcoming season.
_______________________________________________________ “This entire season I missed, it was a very adverse situation,” the 24-year old said. “That obviously wasn’t something I wanted. It happens in football, just like situations happen in life that you have no control over.” Mitchell, a former 2016 fourth-round pick, was dealing with an undisclosed foot injury and was planning to return from the Injured Reserve late in the season. However, Mitchell encountered a setback when he returned to practice and ultimately had to finish the season on I.R.
Mitchell put together a productive 2016 rookie season as he hauled in 32 receptions for 401 yards and four touchdowns and understands the significance of being fully healthy for the team’s offseason program this spring: “This offseason will be big. Obviously I missed all of last season and I won’t shy away from the importance of making sure I’m ready when we start OTAs.” ________________________________________________________

Breaking News: According to reports, the Jacksonville Jaguars released TE Marcedes Lewis.
Lewis, 33, was set to enter the final year of his 3-year/$12M deal and was due a base salary of $3.5M for the 2018 season.
The Jaguars will free up $3.5M of cap space by releasing Lewis, while absorbing 250K of dead money.
Lewis told Mark Long of the AP that he feels “disrespected” by the way the Jaguars handled his release. “I think I deserved a little better than I got. … I wish they would have done it sooner.” The Jaguars exercised Lewis’ 2018 contract option ahead of free agency so there was an understanding that he was returning for the upcoming season. With that being said, Lewis would have preferred to be released before the new league year, so he could have gotten the opportunity to weigh all his options earlier.

Lewis appeared in all 16 games this past season and caught 24 passes for 318 yards and five touchdowns.
Lewis’ tenure with the Jaguars will come to an end after 12 seasons.

NFL News: 49ers’ CEO Jed York made his first public comments on LB Reuben Foster’s two offseason arrests.⬇️ _______________________________________________________ “From my conversations with John and Kyle,” York said, “I know Reuben is very cognizant of where his position is right now. And his time with the 49ers could potentially be over if he continues to do things outside of the team that aren’t what we want him to be a part of.” York said he will make the call on Foster’s status, but says that it’s premature to reach a definitive decision. The Santa Clara County District Attorney’s have not decided whether to pursue criminal charges against Foster for alleged domestic violence, threats, and possession of an assault weapon in Los Gatos. “We have to wait until that happens,” York said. “But that will obviously be something that we get together and discuss whatever comes down when those issues come up and figure out where we move from there.” Foster’s first arrest came in January on misdemeanor marijuana possession charges in Alabama.
York concluded his statement by saying that he may have to part ways with the former 2017 first-round pick if he continues his poor off-the-field behavior. “We’d love Reuben to be on this team. And we’d love him to participate for us, but if he’s not doing things off the field that allow us to be able to rely on him - or he’s doing something that we’re not comfortable with off the field and it’s proven that’s what’s going on — I think the guys have said then you’re just going to have to move on.” _______________________________________________________
Foster, 23, started 10 games for the 49ers this past season and logged 72 tackles and one pass defense.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Former Panthers, Eagles CB Daryl Worley has been charged with violation of the uniform firearms act, driving under the influence, disorderly conduct and other related offenses.
Charging documents indicate that the related offenses include, “possession of an instrument of crime with intent” and resisting arrest.
Police said Worley, 23, was found passed out in a car near Broad Street and Pattison Avenue, outside the team’s practice facility, around 6 a.m. Sunday. He is alleged to have begun fighting with officers who woke him and police used a taser to subdue him, a source close to the situation said, confirming an NFL Network report.
A gun was recovered at the scene, which would seem to not have been properly registered, according to the charges.

He was arraigned and released after posting 10 percent of his $25,000 bail Sunday evening. Worley, who would have made $670K this season, faces a May 1 preliminary hearing.

The Eagles released Worley on Sunday afternoon after acquiring him in a trade from the Panthers last month.
He will be subject to waivers and would become an unrestricted free-agent if he goes unclaimed through the process.

UPDATE: According to reports, the Seattle Seahawks are unlikely to trade CB Richard Sherman this offseason due to his ongoing recovery from a ruptured Achilles.
The Seahawks were open to fielding trade offers for Sherman for a second consecutive offseason, but his inability to pass a physical would negate any potential deal.
Sherman underwent surgery to repair his ruptured Achilles back in November and is facing a 6-8 month recovery, which could keep him out until July.
In addition, Seahawks HC Pete Carroll mentioned today that Sherman recently underwent an additional surgery on his left Achilles to clean up some bone spurs. Carroll added that Sherman will remain in a walking boot for the next couple weeks and is “counting” on him to be cleared for training camp.
If the Seahawks are indeed interested in moving Sherman before the 2018 season, they’d have to wait until he is fully healthy.
Sherman, 29, is set to enter the final year of his 4-year/$56M contract and stands to make a base salary of $11M for the upcoming season.

NFL News: According to reports, the San Francisco 49ers and Denver Broncos have discussed a potential trade involving CB Aqib Talib.
Both teams have been in contact over the last couple of days, but that doesn’t necessarily mean a trade is happening.
Talib reportedly wants to be released instead and is hoping for the opportunity to choose his next team as an unrestricted free-agent.
If Talib is granted a release from the Broncos, the New England Patriots are believed to be his top choice in free agency.
Talib, 32, is set to enter the fifth year of his 6-year/$57M deal and will be under contract through the 2019 season.

NFL News: Rams GM Les Snead says their recent trade acquisitions won’t impact their plan to sign DT Aaron Donald to a long-term contract extension.
_______________________________________________________
"We've got good dialogue with their agents. I'll keep all of that in-house, but none of it affects Aaron Donald," Snead responded during Cooks' introductory news conference Thursday when asked about Donald's contract situation. "He's one of 53 and as I've said plenty of times before, we've got that budgeted into the budget. We didn't do all this and forget about him for sure." Following their recent acquisitions of CBs Marcus Peters, Aqib Talib, WR Brandin Cooks, and DT Ndamukong Suh the Rams are now $3M over the cap. However, they are projected to have the second most salary cap space behind the New York Jets in 2019 with roughly $81M+ at their disposal.
Donald, 26, is set to play out his 2018 fifth-year option and is due to make a base salary of $6.892M. The Rams continue to state their intention to ink him to a new deal and do not believe their current cap situation will hinder their ability to do so.
Snead later went on to say that their busy offseason has them optimistic about contending for many years to come. "Simply put, 2018 is important, we definitely want to repeat as NFC [West] champions," Snead explained. "A lot of the players we've acquired are young and have evolved to be in the prime of their careers and we'd love to take advantage of that, not just '18 but '19, '20, '21 and moving forward.” Snead continued: "2018's important, '19's very important and Sean [McVay] and I have been saying the whole time, that guess what, it's '18 but we're still 11 wins behind the '17 season. Just because we've had a flashy 2018 offseason doesn't mean that we're any better this year than we were last year because we're 11 games behind last year's team. But it's up to us to start here in the next couple weeks, like we did last year and make sure we win 12 or more." Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Giants DC James Bettcher says he admired CB Eli Apple’s skill set coming out college and reiterated that he has a clean slate entering the 2018 season.
_______________________________________________________ “(He’s a) very talented player,” said Bettcher, via SNY.tv. “I (scouted) him when he was coming out in the draft, really liked his skill set. He’s a guy who can play man, who can press, who can play zone defense in space, who can break on the ball.” While Apple has had his issues since arriving in New York, Bettcher stressed that everyone will have a fresh start on Monday. “Day 1 is Monday,” Bettcher said. “That’s how I will answer that. Day 1 is Monday and every guy that walks in that room, Day 1 is Monday. So whatever happened before, whether it was here or whether it was with a different team … Day 1 is the first day those guys walk in the building and we’re going to build from there.” Apple, 22, a former 2016 first-round pick (No. 10 overall), had a turbulent sophomore season and it led many to question his future with the team.
Apple began the 2017 season as the starting outside cornerback, along with Janoris Jenkins, with Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie as the starting slot cornerback. However, Apple tallied just six more starts the rest of the season and tension started to develop between him and his teammates in December.
Apple felt like he was the “scapegoat” in the wake of their defensive struggles and reportedly stormed out of the facility multiple times because of it. His actions led Landon Collins to call him a “cancer” in the locker room and reiterated that Apple needed to “grow up”. On December 27th, 2017, Apple was suspended by former HC Ben McAdoo after reportedly getting into a heated shouting match with the coaching staff about being on the scout team and for a “pattern of behavior that was conduct detrimental to the team”. In seven total starts, Apple finished the season with 49 tackles and eight pass defenses.
Stay tuned for more.

My priority right now is to find a stable home where I can step in and make a similar impact for a few more seasons before I ride off into the sunset. … I’d like to thank Robert Kraft, Coach Belichick, Coach Patricia and the Patriots front office for allowing me to be a part of something that not a lot of players get the opportunity to do – play for the New England Patriots. Playing in Foxboro made me appreciate this game a lot more. Thank you to everyone there for giving me a great experience that I’ll remember for the rest of my life.” Jean-Francois, 31, signed a one-year/$900K contract with the Patriots on December 13th, 2017.

Injury Update: According to reports, Colts HC Frank Reich says QB Andrew Luck (shoulder) has started throwing a football again.
Reich added that Luck is not throwing at “full strength” yet, but expressed optimism over the progress he continues to make in his rehab.
Luck had been throwing non-football items during the earlier stages of his rehab, in order to strengthen his surgically repaired shoulder.
Luck, 28, has not played since 2016, after undergoing surgery on his throwing shoulder to repair a lingering issue that had bothered him since 2015.
Following surgery, Luck was held out of training camp last July and did not receive clearance to play in the preseason. The Colts later announced that he would not be ready for the regular season, which prompted the team to start Scott Tolzien in Week 1.
The Colts then went on to acquire Jacoby Brissett from the New England Patriots and started him for the remainder of the 2017 season.
The Colts later placed Luck on the Injured Reserve on November 2nd, officially ending his season.

NFL News: According to reports, Giants impending free-agent LB Mark Herzlich hopes to return for the 2018 season.
Herzlich says he has already spoken with new HC Pat Shurmur and GM Dave Gettleman: "I've gone in and I had a nice conversation (with Shurmur)," Herzlich told NJ.com. "I stopped by the other day and met some of the other coaches. I sat down with Gettleman. It seems like a really good vibe." Herzlich added that he will not rush into a decision when free agency begins: "I'm in no hurry to be going anywhere," said Herzlich. "So we'll see how the next couple of months progress. If the Giants stay my home, which would be fantastic, then I feel like I'm in great hands. I've got great coaches and a great general manager and then obviously the Tisches and the Maras, whether I'm playing for the Giants or not, they're always family. It's a great place to be." Herzlich’s one-year/$855K contract is set to expire and he will become an unrestricted free-agent next month.
Herzlich, 30, missed the entire 2017 season after suffering a stinger injury in Training Camp.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Redskins HC Jay Gruden says they will consider selecting a running back early in the 2018 NFL Draft.
Gruden joined Grant Paulsen and Craig Hoffman on 106.7 The Fan and here’s what he had to say when asked about the possibility of drafting a running back high. “That’s a good possibility, yes,” Gruden said. “We have a lot of running backs on our roster. … We got to look at a lot of running backs last year, unfortunately, with injuries. Byron Marshall came in and he showed flashes of being a pretty good player after we plucked him from Philly’s practice squad, but he pulled his hamstring pretty bad. We got Kapri Bibbs, we looked at him, he did a nice job for us the last couple games of the year. Obviously, Chris Thompson coming back, Rob Kelley coming back at full strength. Rob had a really good game against the Rams, hurt his ankle and then he was never really full strength. Samaje [Perine] got some quality reps as a rookie running back and did some good things for his first year. We expect major improvement from him. So we have some guys in house that we feel pretty comfortable about, but it would be nice, possibly, to add another, maybe a first- [or] second-down back that can give us a little bit of juice to help us out.” The Redskins currently have RBs Rob Kelley, Samaje Perine, Chris Thompson, and Kapri Bibbs on their roster.
Washington currently holds the 13th overall pick of the 2018 NFL Draft. Their second round pick is 44th overall.

UPDATE: According to reports, Cowboys DE Randy Gregory is receiving encouraging signs regarding his chances for NFL reinstatement.
Gregory was in the process of filing for reinstatement last month and it appears his representatives have received promising reports about his eligibility to make an NFL return.
There is no firm deadline for Commissioner Roger Goodell to approve or deny Gregory’s reinstatement bid.
Gregory, 25, is a former 2015 second-round pick and has only played in 14 career games since entering the league. He missed four games during his rookie season due to a high-ankle sprain, but still managed to appear in 12 games.
Gregory’s troubles began in 2016 when he was suspended a total of 14 games for violating the league’s substance abuse policy twice. In result, Gregory played in the team’s final two regular season games before being suspended for the entire 2017 season following a third failed drug test.
Gregory has spent time at multiple drug rehab centers and is reportedly in good physical and mental shape. He is currently training in California as he continues to work his way back into football condition.
It’s worth noting that the last two years have not counted as accrued seasons towards Gregory’s free-agent status. With that being said, the Cowboys will have him under contract through 2020 if he is granted reinstatement.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the Green Bay Packers attempted to negotiate a pay cut with RT Bryan Bulaga earlier this offseason.

Bulaga’s future in Green Bay appears to be safe at the moment, but he could be a potential cap causality following the 2018 season, considering that he will be entering the final year of his deal in 2019.
Bulaga, 29, is a former first-round pick of the Packers back in 2010. He’s currently entering the fourth year of his five-year, $33.75M contract and stands to make base salaries of $5.85M and $5.8M over the final two years of the agreement.

NFL News: Raiders QB Derek Carr admits that his back injury played a factor in his regression this season.
_______________________________________________________ “When you break three bones in your back, it doesn’t feel good,” Carr said, via Scott Bair of NBC Sports Bay Area. “I’m thankful God healed me to the point I could walk around and be able to practice. Injuries will never be something I talk about, especially during the season, but since it’s after the season, the (back issue) was one of those things that was there.” Carr is talking about the transverse process fractures he suffered early in the season. Carr ended up playing with the injury in every game except one. He said he was pushing for a quick return, regardless of him not feeling 100 percent. “I had to deal with it,” Carr said. “I had to do certain things to manage it, but I just didn’t talk about it. I didn’t want it to be an excuse. It was a want more than anything else. I didn’t want it to be a reason. I couldn’t let that be a reason why I couldn’t do A, B or C.” _______________________________________________________

Carr, who was selected to replace Tom Brady in the Pro Bowl on Monday, struggled to find a rhythm this past season.
In 15 starts, Carr threw for 3,496 yards, 22 touchdowns and 13 interceptions to go along with a 62.7 completion percentage.

NFL News: According to reports, the Buffalo Bills will gauge the trade market for QB Tyrod Taylor this offseason.
Taylor, 28, is set to enter the final year of his 2-year/$30.5M contract and stands to make a base salary of $10M for the 2018 season.
While Taylor has been vocal about his unwillingness to accept a pay cut to remain with the team, the Bills do not plan to release him outright.
Bills’ executives are well aware of the current demand for starting quarterbacks and they are confident that they will receive multiple trade offers for Taylor. In this sense, the Bills would avoid parting ways with Taylor for nothing in return, which is their primary plan entering the offseason.
When the Bills hired new GM Brandon Beane and HC Sean McDermott, Taylor’s days in Buffalo were numbered.
The new regime knew they wanted to acquire their own franchise quarterback when they took over and benching Taylor this past season proved just that. With that being said, Taylor is very likely to be playing elsewhere next season and he shouldn’t have any shortage of interested suitors.
The Bills would save $10.44M of cap space by trading Taylor, while taking on $7.64M of dead money.
In 14 starts this season, Taylor went 8-6 and threw for 2,799 yards, 14 touchdowns and four interceptions to go along with a 62.6 completion percentage. In addition, Taylor rushed for 427 yards on 84 carries (5.1 YPC) and four touchdowns.
Stay tuned for more.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the New York Giants view Penn State RB Saquon Barkley as “a near-perfect prospect” and are leaning towards selecting him with their No. 2 overall pick.
There has been plenty of speculation regarding the Giants’ direction at No. 2 overall. Should they go with a quarterback to be Eli Manning’s future successor? Should they trade back with the Buffalo Bills for additional draft picks? Well, it appears we may be getting some answers as the draft rapidly approaches.
According to the New York Post, the Giants are increasingly unlikely to select a quarterback or trade down from their second overall pick. That essentially narrows down their options to selecting Barkley or NC State DE Bradley Chubb.
With that being said, the Giants reportedly favor Barkley over Chubb because of the immediate impact he can make.
One of the reasons the Giants may be fading away from potentially taking a quarterback at 2, is because of their inability to agree on who the best signal caller is of the 2018 class. GM Dave Gettleman reportedly covets USC QB Sam Darnold, while other team executives favor UCLA’s Josh Rosen and Wyoming’s Josh Allen.
In result, New York seems to be steering away from selecting a quarterback, which bodes well for Barkley’s chances to become a Giant on draft night.
Stay tuned for more.

2018 NFL Draft: UCLA QB Josh Rosen joined ESPN’s Sam Alipour for a recent interview and explained why he’s the best quarterback of the draft class. "I'm the best QB in the draft. A lot of guys are flashier, but I think I'm the most efficient, monotonously consistent QB in this draft," Rosen told Alipour. "[Aaron] Rodgers has some flair, but if you watch Tom Brady, Peyton Manning, Drew Brees, there's nothing that's explosive or Johnny Manziel -- like. It's just quarterbacking." Rosen added that he wants to be the best quarterback to ever play at the position: "I want to be great -- in everything I do," Rosen said. "As far as football, I always looked up to Kellen Moore of Boise State. I thought it was the coolest thing that he was the winningest QB of all time. I thought that was a cool word: winningest. So I want to be the winningest QB in NFL history. I want to win the most games and most championships. I'd say six titles, but if Tom Brady gets six, I'll say seven." Rosen compiled 9,340 pass yards, 59 touchdowns and 26 interceptions to go along with a 60.9 completion percentage during his three year collegiate career at UCLA.

NFL News: Bills HC Sean McDermott confirmed that they will not release QB Tyrod Taylor this offseason.
When asked about Taylor’s uncertain future in Buffalo, here’s what McDermott had to say: “It's way too early to take anything off the table other than cutting him at this point, which is not in our plans." Taylor, 28, is due a roster bonus of $6M by the third day of the new league year, but that is not an issue for the Bills at this point in time.
The Bills are reportedly willing to pay Taylor his roster bonus and are comfortable with retaining him at his current $10M salary for the 2018 season. However, the Bills do plan to field trade offers for Taylor this offseason and could move him for the right price.
Taylor started 14 games this season and threw for 2,799 yards, 14 touchdowns, and four interceptions to go along with a 62.6 completion percentage. In addition, Taylor rushed for 427 yards on 84 carries (5.1 YPC) and four touchdowns.
Stay tuned for more.

DEVELOPING: According to reports, the Miami Dolphins are seriously considering the possibility of releasing DT Ndamukong Suh.
Suh, 31, is set to enter the fourth year of his 6-year/$114.375M contract ($59.95 guaranteed) and stands to make a base salary of $16.985M for the 2018 season season. That is not the entire issue with Suh’s contract.
Suh’s $26.1M cap hit for the upcoming season is the most by any defensive player, the most by any non-quarterback, and third overall behind quarterbacks Jimmy Garoppolo ($37M) and Matthew Stafford ($26.5M). The Dolphins can also trade Suh and save $3.9M in cap space and get compensation in return, as opposed to cutting him loose for nothing. However, it will be difficult for the Dolphins to find a trade partner that would be willing to absorb Suh’s contract.
With that being said, Miami is likely to release him outright, which would save them $3.9M of cap space. In this case, they’d be taking on $22.2M of dead money.
Miami can also designate Suh as a post-June 1 cut, which would save the team $8.5M in cap space, while absorbing $17.6M of dead money. This is the most ideal option for the Dolphins if they decide to move on from Suh.
Suh started all 16 games this season and posted 48 total tackles, 4.5 sacks, two forced fumbles, and two pass defenses.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Former Raiders OLB Aldon Smith was arrested again for violating a condition of his bail.
Smith was in court last Thursday for allegedly violating a protective order after his arrest for domestic violence. The judge ordered Smith to wear a GPS and a SCRAM device to measure the amount of alcohol content in his sweat.

Smith’s latest arrest came for violating a condition of his electronic monitoring.

Smith was booked into the San Francisco County Jail around 5 PM Friday night and is being held on $500,000 bond. He’s due back in court April 11th.

This is Smith’s fourth arrest in the past few months.

The Raiders released Smith from the reserve/retired list shortly following his arrest for alleged domestic violence on March 5th.
Smith, 28, is a former 2010 first-round pick of the San Francisco 49ers.

NFL News: According to reports, There is “strong support” for QB Teddy Bridgewater within the Minnesota Vikings’ organization.
As the Vikings get set to enter an offseason full of uncertainty regarding their quarterback situation, it appears no love has been lost for Bridgewater, despite Case Keenum’s strong season.
Vikings HC Mike Zimmer never ruled out the possibility of Bridgewater taking over as the starting quarterback when he returned to full health and it’s a testament to how much respect he has for the former 2014 first-round pick.
Bridgewater hasn’t played a full season since 2015 when he threw for 3,231 yards, 14 touchdowns and nine interceptions to go along with a 65.3 completion percentage. The Vikings posted an 11-5 record that season and went on to lose a 10-9 wildcard playoff game to the Seattle Seahawks.
Vikings GM Rick Spielman did not reveal any of the team’s plans at quarterback when he joined NFL Network earlier today, but their loyalty to Bridgewater could lead them to move on from Keenum and Sam Bradford this offseason.

Veteran CB Antonio Cromartie has announced his retirement.
Today is the day I️ knew I️ would eventually have to face, but one I never wanted to accept. After 27 years of playing football, today I say farewell. God blessed me with the opportunity to play in the NFL for 11 years, and after much consideration and prayer, I’d like to officially announce my retirement.

Throughout my career so many people have helped strengthen and guide me. I’d love to send my sincere thanks to my Coaching Staff, Trainers, Chaplains and Fellow Teammates. To my agents Gary Wichard (Rest Easy G), and Ben Dorga, thank you for not only guiding me throughout my career, but also for making me feel like family and not a client.

To The San Diego Chargers and the Spanos Family, thank you for believing in me. Thank you for taking a chance on a young kid from Tallahassee, Florida who did not play much in college. You believed in my ability and my potential to play at a professional level, and I️ will forever be grateful. To all the Charger Fans; thank you for your love, your support and never giving up on me throughout my career. To my "Bird Gang Family, “The Arizona Cardinals” and the Bidwell Family; although my time with you was short, I️ enjoyed my year there and I loved the opportunity you gave me. It was an honor to play for such a great organization. To my
J-E-T-S, JETS, JETS, JETS, The Best NFL Team in New York, The Jets Organization. You became my home and my family. I grew as a player, a man, and as a leader. The brotherhood I️ built here was undeniable. My heart will forever embrace the feeling of running through the tunnel and out onto the field with my brothers. My family and I will forever Bleed Green. JETUP, JET NATION.

To my lovely wife Terricka, thank you for your support through the ups and downs of my career. You were always there to encourage me, and push me. Because of you I became a better player, and a man. I thank God, for a praying wife for I know it was your prayers that sustained me, and protected me while I was on the field.
As we take on this next chapter of our lives, I will hold onto your words.. “Football is your Platform Antonio; It’s Not Your Purpose”.

NFL News: Vikings OLB Anthony Barr says he wants to sign a long-term deal to remain in Minnesota.

I really love this team. I love the city. I could see myself being here for the future.’’ Barr didn’t want to get into specifics regarding the type of money he would be looking for in terms of a long-term deal from the Vikings, but said he would like to be “secure.” “I don’t really worry about that kind of stuff,’’ Barr said. “Money comes and goes, so I’ll be happy just to be secure.’’ Barr, 25, played out the final year of his 4-year/$12.73M rookie contract and stands to make a base salary of $12.306M under his 2018 fifth-year option.

NFL News: Patriots TE Rob Gronkowski says he will evaluate his future playing career this offseason and is noncommittal about returning for the 2018 season.
Here’s what Gronkowski had to say when asked about the possibility of retirement: “I don’t know how you heard that, but I mean I’m definitely gonna look at my future for sure,” Gronkowski said, via Pro Football Talk. “Sit down the next couple weeks and see where I’m at.” Gronkowski, 28, has dealt with a number of serious injuries throughout his career including multiple concussions to go along with ACL and back surgeries.
Gronkowski is set to enter the seventh year of his 8-year/$55.23M contract and stands to make base salaries of $8M and $9M over the final two years of the agreement.
Stay tuned for more.

________________________________________________________

NFL News: Bears TE Zach Miller is hoping to continue his playing career, despite suffering a gruesome knee injury earlier this season.
Miller tells Scott Voorhees on 1110 KFAB that he’s aware a comeback may not be in the cards for him and if it isn’t, “then that’s just the way it goes and we’ve got to move on and do something else.” The hardest part of returning from a serious knee injury, according to Miller, is the mental hurdles he’ll have to overcome: “Physically I’ve been through a number of surgeries or whatever it may be,” Miller said. “I can recover from that. But the mental aspect is something you’ve got to learn how to work it, how to block out some stuff and really just stay positive, which I’ve done a pretty good job doing.” Miller mentioned that seeing photos of the injury is difficult and added that he may not ever watch the video. “I’ve seen still shots of it, pictures of it, on accident,” Miller said. “Maybe a week ago was the first time I was able to look at the picture and not turn away. I don’t know if I’ll watch the video, if I ever will.” Miller, 33, played out the final year of his 2-year/$5.5M contract and is scheduled to become an unrestricted free-agent in March.
In six starts this season, Miller hauled in 20 receptions for 236 yards and two touchdowns.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL Picks📊: AFC Championship
No. 3 Jacksonville Jaguars @ No. 1 New England Patriots
Championship Sunday is officially here. The Jacksonville Jaguars will be looking to book their first trip to the Super Bowl, while the New England Patriots continue their quest to repeat as champions.
This matchup is interesting because the Jaguars' defense matches up very well with the Patriots' high-powered offense. I do believe the Jags have a chance to pull the upset due to their No. 1 ranked rush offense. I expect Leonard Fournette to have success on the ground against a New England defense that finished 20th in rush defense. Winning time of possession for Jacksonville will be crucial for their chances to escape Foxborough with a victory. Keeping Brady off the field should be their top priority and I think they will do a nice job of accomplishing that today. I look for Todd Wash to keep his defensive philosophy the same. Consistent blitzing, man coverage, and aggressive playcalling in short-yardage situations. In result, the Jags will create havoc and disrupt Brady's rhythm in the pocket. I expect Jacksonville to pile up at least six sacks on Brady and it will limit the Patriots' offensive efficiency throughout. However, I still think the brain power of Belichick, Josh McDaniels, and Brady will be able to make timely second-half adjustments that will pay dividends for them in the long-run. Rob Gronkowski may face Jalen Ramsey, but I still look for him to reach 80+ yards receiving and a touchdown. The Patriots' defense has feasted on turnovers during the playoffs, and I expect them to come away with an interception off Bortles to swing momentum their way in the fourth quarter. This game will come down to the wire, with Jacksonville leading the game with under five minutes to play in regulation. But, somehow, someway, Brady will find a way to engineer a game-winning drive to send the Patriots to Super Bowl 52. New England wins a thriller, 23-21.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the New England Patriots will explore the possibility of trading up for a quarterback.
Patriots HC Bill Belichick made the decision to trade QB Jimmy Garoppolo to the San Francisco 49ers for a 2018 second-round pick back in October. There was plenty of controversy swirling around the Patriots’ organization after the move was made, considering Tom Brady’s age and their need for his future successor.
Brady, 40, will be returning for his 19th NFL season and isn’t showing any signs of slowing down anytime soon. However, the Patriots know they need to identify Brady’s heir in the immediate future and will almost certainly select a quarterback in the upcoming NFL Draft.
The Patriots acquired a 2018 first-round pick (No. 23 overall) from the Los Angeles Rams in exchange for WR Brandin Cooks on Tuesday. This now gives them a bevy of premium picks to use for a potential trade up into the top-10, should a quarterback of their liking be available.
The Patriots are set to enter this year’s draft with five picks in the top 100, with four of those being in the top two rounds: No. 23, No. 31, No. 43, No. 63, and No. 95.
No one knows which signal caller is on the the Patriots’ radar, but all signs are pointing toward them selecting their future franchise quarterback if the right opportunity presents itself.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Eagles WR Torrey Smith says he is expecting to be back with the team for the 2018 season, but understands that it’s a business.
_______________________________________________________ “I’m expecting to be back, but I know how the business goes,” Smith said before watching his alma mater Maryland play Michigan in basketball. “There would never be any hard feelings. How can you be mad at someone who gave you a chance to win a ring.” Smith continued, “I don’t know how it’s going to play out, but I’m expecting to be back, and I definitely want to be back.” Smith, 29, signed a 3-year/$15M deal with the Eagles last offseason, but the final two years of his contract are team options.
Smith is set to make a base salary of $5M for the 2018 and 2019 seasons and it remains to be known if the Eagles will retain him, considering their salary cap situation entering the offseason.
The Eagles will need to make a decision on picking up his 2018 contract option by March 14th, the start of the new league year.
Smith appeared in all 16 games this season (14 starts) hauled in 36 receptions for 430 yards and two touchdowns.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Texans owner Bob McNair says he regrets saying sorry when he compared NFL players to “inmates running the prison” last year.
McNair told the Wall Street Journal that he doesn’t believe he did anything wrong and doesn’t think he should have been pressured to give an apology. “The main thing I regret is apologizing,” McNair said.
He insists the “inmates” he was referring to were not NFL players, but rather league executives who he felt had more power over major decisions than the owners. “I really didn’t have anything to apologize for.” McNair said he views nothing objectionable about his comments at a league meeting and thinks if people were offended, that just means they misunderstood him. “In business, it’s a common expression. But the general public doesn’t understand it, perhaps,” he said.

McNair also denied what former Texans OT Duane Brown told PFT last year, stating that McNair had expressed displeasure to the team in 2008 after Barack Obama was elected as president. “I don’t go into meetings and express views like that,” McNair said. “I never said that. He has no problem saying things that are not true.” ________________________________________________________

NFL News: According to reports, the Cleveland Browns will make a strong push to sign Bengals impending free-agent QB A.J. McCarron.
The Browns are after McCarron yet again, but luckily for them, he’ll be an unrestricted free-agent this time around.
As we all know by now, the Browns botched the paperwork of an agreed trade they had with the Cincinnati Bengals, which negated them from acquiring McCarron ahead of the deadline this past season.
Browns HC Hue Jackson has ties to McCarron as he served as the Bengals’ offensive coordinator when he (McCarron) was selected in the fifth-round of the 2014 NFL Draft.
Jackson has consulted with GM John Dorsey and team personnel and they all appear to be on board with the idea of pursuing McCarron in free agency.
If the Browns do sign McCarron, that will not stop them from drafting a signal caller with one of their top picks. Their plan is to select a quarterback to allow him the time to develop behind McCarron.
McCarron, 27, won his grievance against the Bengals and will become an unrestricted free-agent when the new league year begins.
Stay tuned for more.
