NFL News: Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti says the team “considered” firing HC John Harbaugh after this season.
Here’s what Bisciotti had to say when asked about the possibility of making a head coaching change: “It was a consideration but it wasn’t one I was inclined to make,” Bisciotti said, per Jamison Hensley.

Bisciotti did, however, say that he is not going to give a playoff or bust edict to Harbaugh this season. “If I was going to do that, I might as well fire him now,” Bisciotti said, per Hensley. “That’s not a way to run a business.” The Ravens signed Harbaugh to a contract extension that will keep him under team control through the 2019 season. However, there’s been a lot of talk about Harbaugh’s job security due to the Ravens missing the playoffs the last three seasons.
Harbaugh, 55, has posted a 94-66 record through ten seasons as the Ravens’ head coach. Harbaugh has led the Ravens to six playoff appearances and one Super Bowl championship in 2012.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Former Rams WR Stedman Bailey recently joined Bleacher Report’s Tyler Dunn for an interview and reiterated his intention to make an NFL comeback. "I'm ready to show the world that I can't be stopped," he said.

Bailey says his goal is to earn a spot on an NFL roster and win Comeback Player of the Year honors in 2018. "You've seen dudes come back from ACLs, Achilles, broken bones," Bailey said. "I want to be the one to show people that no matter what you go through, you don't have to let other people define who you are as a person, what you can do as a person -- and I can show the world anything is possible. "I know when I step on the field, there's a 100 percent chance I win Comeback Player of the Year. And then I'll get up on the stage and just blow you away with all that I've been through." Bailey already has his first touchdown celebration planned out if he gets an opportunity to return. "I'm taking my helmet off so everybody can see," Bailey said of the scar that runs across his skull. "Helmet. Off." Bailey, 27, participated in Marshall’s pro day last month and continues to train with NFL players, including Rams RB Todd Gurley.
Bailey, a former 2013 third-round pick, hasn’t played since suffering two gun shot wounds to the head in November of 2015. @steddyambition @gmfb
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the Jacksonville Jaguars will attempt to acquire Chiefs QB Alex Smith or Redskins QB Kirk Cousins this offseason.

If they are successful in doing so, the Jags would look to release Bortles before March 14th. Releasing Bortles before then would clear his entire $19.053M salary off the books. 2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the Miami Dolphins have strong interest in Washington State QB Luke Falk.

The Dolphins haven’t been shy about their interest in drafting a signal caller as they’ve certainly done extensive homework on multiple quarterback prospects.
Ryan Tannehill is on his way back from an ACL surgery that ended his 2017 season and while HC Adam Gase has voiced his support of him being their starter, it hasn’t stopped them from exploring other options in the upcoming draft class.
The Dolphins have also expressed interest in Oklahoma QB Baker Mayfield and have met with him several times during the pre-draft process. However, they are well aware of their slim chances to land him in round one, considering their current positioning with the 11th overall pick.
With that being said, Gase has done a lot of background work on Falk and believes he’s a player that can be developed in his offensive system.
The Dolphins have already held a formal visit with Falk and view him as a viable option on day two of the NFL Draft.
Falk, who stands 6’4”, 225lbs, threw for 3,593 yards, 30 touchdowns and 13 interceptions to go along with a 66.9 completion percentage during his senior season at Washington State.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, Eagles DE Michael Bennett is expected to turn himself in on Monday.
Bennett was indicted by the Harris County District Attorney’s office for a felony charge of injuring a 66-year-old paraplegic working at NRG stadium to control field access at Super Bowl LI.
Bennett, 32, could face up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine. A warrant for his arrest was issued on Friday.
Bennett is represented by Rusty Hardin, a prominent Houston defense attorney who has represented Roger Clemens and other high-profile clients.
Per Jeff McLane of the Philadelphia Inquirer, Hardin mentioned that Bennett is currently out of the continental United States and reiterated that he has not yet met his client. With that being said, Hardin will refrain from making any public comments at this time.
Bennett is set to enter the first year of his new 3-year/$30.5M contract and is due base salaries of $1.65M, $6M, and $7.5M over the next three seasons.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Eagles QB Carson Wentz spoke to the media today and reiterated that he will not change his style of play, despite his knee injury last season.
Wentz tore his ACL and LCL in a December game against the Los Angeles Rams and says he is still aiming to be ready for Week 1 of the regular season. "Yeah, that's still the goal," Wentz told reporters at a media day on Tuesday at NovaCare Complex, the team's training facility.

Wentz added that he’s started the running phase of his rehab: "We've started the running progression and all those things," Wentz said. "I'm feeling good. I'm feeling good with where I'm at. Just trying to stay the course. But, like I said late last season, it's such a fluid process. It's so hard to put a time frame and a timetable on these things. I wish I knew, as well." Wentz, 25, started 13 games for the Eagles this past season (11-2 record) and threw for 33 touchdowns and seven interceptions to go along with a 60.2 completion percentage. He also rushed for 299 yards on 64 attempts (4.7 YPC). ________________________________________________________

UPDATE: According to reports, Cowboys owner Jerry Jones confirmed that DE Randy Gregory is in the process of filing for reinstatement from the NFL.
Gregory, a former 2015 second-round pick, has only played in 14 career games since entering the league.
With that being said, Jones is optimistic about Gregory’s potential reinstatement and hopes he can contribute in the 2018 season.
Gregory, 25, missed four games during his rookie season due to a high-ankle sprain, but still managed to appear in 12 games.
However, Gregory’s troubles began in 2016 when he was suspended a total of 14 games for violating the league’s substance abuse policy twice. In result, Gregory played in the team’s final two regular season games before being suspended for an entire year following a third failed drug test.
Gregory missed the entire 2017 season due to suspension, but it appears he is making an attempt to regain eligibility for the upcoming 2018 season.
Gregory has spent time at multiple drug rehab centers and is reportedly in good physical and mental shape. He is currently training in California as he continues to work his way back into football condition.
While his chance for reinstatement is far from guaranteed, Gregory is certainly looking into the matter and is hoping to get another opportunity to play.
It’s worth noting that the last two years have not counted as accrued seasons toward Gregory’s free-agent status. With that being said, the Cowboys will have him under contract through 2020 if he is granted reinstatement.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, Browns WR Josh Gordon will become a restricted free-agent next month.
Many league executives were under the impression that Gordon was going to become an exclusive rights free-agent this offseason, but that is not the case, according to the NFL Players Association.
If Gordon was indeed slated to become an exclusive rights free-agent, the Browns would simply have to extend an ERFA tender in order to retain his rights at a low cost for the 2018 season.
However, since Gordon is scheduled to become a restricted free-agent, the Browns will now have to decide if they will place a first-round ($4.15M), second-round ($2.92), or an original-round tender ($1.91M) on him. Placing a tender on Gordon would permit teams to part ways with a draft pick of listed value, should they sign him to a deal.
If they choose not to place a restricted tender on him, Gordon would become an unrestricted free-agent in March.
Gordon is a former 2012 second-round supplemental pick of the Browns and was suspended for the 2015 and 2016 seasons due to violating the league’s substance abuse policy.
Gordon, 26, started five games this season and hauled in 18 receptions for 335 yards and one touchdown.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: Rusty Hardin, the attorney for Eagles DE Michael Bennett, says his client will plead not guilty to his felony charge.
_______________________________________________________
“The only two possible outcomes for this case is the DA’s office [saying] they don’t have a case and dismissing, or a trial — one or the other,” Hardin said. “If and whenever they ask for a plea, it will be not guilty.” Hardin has said that he believes that Bennett is innocent. “I just don’t think he did it,” Hardin said. “He certainly didn’t do anything intentionally, or negligibly or recklessly push or hurt her. Now, did something else happen to her from somebody else? I just don’t know. “I think the bigger issue is there were a bunch of people going through that door, anywhere from 20 to 35 people rushing to go down on the field to see their loved ones and celebrate with them. He and his family were with a group of other Patriot family members, and when the game was over, these different families all went to the floor. “… I just know that this guy would never intentionally or knowingly push her or do anything to somebody in a wheelchair. That just didn’t happen.” Bennett was recently indicted on a felony charge of injury of the elderly stemming from an incident that occurred last February in Houston. Bennett turned himself in to police earlier this week.

Bennett is accused of injuring a 66-year-old paraplegic who was working at NRG Stadium to control access to the field at Super Bowl LI.
Bennett was in attendance to watch his brother, Martellus, play in the Super Bowl for the Patriots.

Bennett allegedly shoved his way onto to the field following the game injuring the elderly woman. He could face up to ten years in prison and a $10,000 fine.

Bennett, 32, is entering the first year of his new 3-year/$30.5M deal and is due to make base salaries of $1.65M, $6M, and $7.5M over the three years of the agreement.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Veteran RB Fred Jackson is planning to sign a one-day contract with the Buffalo Bills to officially retire as a member of the team. “Have it in the works now,” Jackson said, via Nick Veronica of the Buffalo News. “That’s the plan, to come back and show Buffalo that my career in Buffalo was the most important thing to me in my football career and I would love to retire as a Buffalo Bill.” “We’re in the works of talking and trying to work something out that will benefit both myself and Buffalo in making it happen.” Jackson said in June of last year that he did not intend on retiring and was hoping for another opportunity, but was not able to land a contract.

Jackson, 37, is a former undrafted free-agent out of Coe College back in 2006. He spent eight years in Buffalo before signing with the Seattle Seahawks ahead of the 2015 season.

After his brief stint in Seattle, Jackson wound up sitting out the 2016 and 2017 NFL seasons. He attempted a comeback after the 2016 season by signing with The Spring League for its summer showcase, but again wasn’t able to garner any interest.
In 2015, Jackson appeared in all 16 games for the Seahawks and rushed for 100 yards on 26 carries (3.8 YPC) to go along with 32 receptions for 257 yards receiving and two touchdowns.

Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, the Arizona Cardinals still have free-agent S Tre Boston on their radar and will consider signing him if he lowers his asking price.
Boston joined SiriusXM NFL radio on March 30th and expressed his frustration with the slow moving market for safeties.
He mentioned that he is seeking a contract worth $7M-$8M per year, but teams have been resistant to spend anywhere close to that price tag for him and other players at his position.
Boston added that the Cardinals, Oakland Raiders, Cleveland Browns, and New York Giants had all expressed preliminary interest in him, but it appears just one of those teams still has him on their radar.
Arizona is reportedly monitoring Boston’s contract demands and would explore the idea of signing him, should both sides find common ground on a deal. However, the Cardinals will likely wait until after the NFL Draft before they approach Boston about a potential contract.
Boston does not expect to re-sign with the Chargers due to him being at an “impasse” with them over where he should play in Gus Bradley’s defense. They reportedly view him as a strong safety and Boston claims he’s better suited to play free safety.
Boston, 25, started 15 games for the Chargers this past season and recorded 79 tackles, five interceptions, and eight pass defenses.

This Just In: Stephanie Rickard, the attorney for 49ers’ LB Reuben Foster‘s girlfriend, said in a statement to the Sacramento Bee that she initially lied to police and informed them that Foster did not injure her during the incident that occurred at his home in Los Gatos back in February. “(Foster) did not strike her, injure her or threaten her,” said Rickard.

She says Foster tried to end the relationship with her, which led to the fight. “She was extremely upset and told him if he broke up with her she would ‘trash his career,’” Rickard said.

According to Rickard, Foster’s girlfriend told local prosecutors that she wanted to recant but that the district attorney’s office filed charges anyway.

Foster is facing charges of domestic violence with an allegation that he inflicted great bodily injury, forcefully attempting to prevent a victim from reporting a crime, and possession of an assault weapon – all felonies. He was also charged with misdemeanor possession of large capacity weapon magazine. If convicted, he faces more than 11 years in prison.

It remains unclear what Foster’s next steps are, but the new evidence should result in all of his charges being dropped due to invalid information.
Foster, 24, is a former first-round pick of the 49ers back in 2017. He’s entering the second year of his 4-year/$9.03M contract and stands to make base salaries of $875K and $1.28M over the next two years of the agreement.

Jaguars HC Doug Marrone dodged questions about Bortles being the team’s quarterback after Sunday’s loss to the Patriots. “I would really have to take a step back and look at it,” Marrone said. “I don’t think I’m in the best mindset to talk about any of our players from that standpoint. … Now it’s a matter of taking a step back and giving myself some time and looking at things as a whole.” Bortles, 26, finished playing out his 4-year/$20.65M rookie contract and stands to make a base salary of $19M under his fifth-year option for the 2018 season.

UPDATE: Broncos executive VP John Elway is non-committal about RB C.J. Anderson’s future with the team.
Elway was asked this evening if Anderson will be on their roster for the 2018 season and here is what he had to say: “He may or may not. Who knows? We’re going to continue to massage this thing, figure out what’s best. C.J. obviously had a great year for us. We’ll see where it takes us. There’s a lot of moving parts when you talk about cap and type things.” The Broncos are reportedly intent on making former 2016 fourth-round RB Devontae Booker the featured back for the 2018 season and are looking to move Anderson to make that happen.
The Broncos placed Anderson on the trade block in mid-February, but have yet to receive any real interest from teams.
Anderson, 27, is set to enter the third year of his 4-year/$18M contract and stands to make a base salary of $4.5M for the 2018 and 2019 seasons.
Denver wants to avoid releasing Anderson outright and are hoping to receive at least a mid-round pick in any trade for him. However, if his trade market doesn’t accelerate by the conclusion of the 2018 NFL Draft, they may consider the possibility of cutting him without compensation.
Anderson started all 16 games this past season and rushed for 1,007 yards on 245 attempts (4.1 YPC) and three touchdowns. Anderson also hauled in 28 receptions for 224 yards and one touchdown.
The Broncos would free up $4.5M of cap space by trading or releasing Anderson this offseason.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Free-agent WR Victor Cruz hopes to sign with a team this offseason, despite sitting out the 2017 season.
_______________________________________________________ “I’m not retired just yet,” said Cruz, via Ryan Dunleavy. “I’m going to give it one more shot and see what’s out there, see what’s in the market for me and if I can get into anybody’s camp. If not, we’ll see where it goes after that and take the necessary steps.” Cruz said he was surprised that he didn’t receive interest from the Giants after he was released by the Bears in September, given that he knew their offense and they were thin at the position. “Naturally, I was surprised, being that I knew the offense and was just there a few months ago at that point,” Cruz said. “I was a little bit surprised just as a normal human being just as everybody else I came across was surprised as they (said) to me everywhere I go.” Cruz feels that he proved he could stay healthy during his final season with the Giants and believes he is still capable of making “game-changing” plays. “I think I proved that (healthy) in the last year with the Giants,” Cruz said. “I was still making game-changing plays throughout that year, although they came few and far between.” Cruz, 31, signed a one-year deal with the Bears last May, but was released on September 2nd leading up to Week 1 of the regular season.

NFL News: According to reports, Many league executives are not convinced that Patriots HC Bill Belichick will return for the 2018 season.
Belichick, 65, reiterated his intention to return next season on many occasions, but there are still many executives around the league that aren’t buying into the idea.
The Patriots’ coaching staff is experiencing a lot of turnover this offseason after losing DC Matt Patricia (Lions), OC Josh McDaniels (Colts), ST coordinator Joe Judge (Colts), and assistant QBs coach Jerry Schuplinski (Colts). Some members within the Patriots’ organization don’t believe Belichick is at the stage of his career to have any desire to reboot his staff with new coordinators. In addition, the reported “power struggle” between Belichick, Robert Kraft, and Tom Brady could play a factor in Belichick’s premature exit from coaching.
At this point, it’s still too early to make any firm opinions on Belichick’s future in New England, but many can agree that there is some uncertainty as the offseason gets underway.
Stay tuned for more.
________________________________________________________

NFL News: According to reports, the Atlanta Falcons and Seattle Seahawks have expressed interest in Jets impending free-agent TE Austin Seferian-Jenkins.

With that being said, Seferian-Jenkins has already turned down an offer worth $4M per year from the Jets and is reportedly seeking a deal that would pay him $6M annually.
With free agency three days away, Seferian-Jenkins is garnering interest from the Falcons and Seahawks and is expected to have a strong market.
Seferian-Jenkins, 25, played out his four-year/$5.254M rookie contract and is now set to become an unrestricted free-agent.
Seferian-Jenkins appeared in 13 games (10 starts) and caught 50 passes for 357 yards, and three touchdowns.

NFL News: Jets impending free-agent QB Josh McCown says he wants to continue his playing career next season. “Right now, that’s how it’s looking,” McCown said regarding continuing his career, via Connor Hughes of NJ Advance Media. “At this time of the year, I go through those conversations with my family, talk with them through that, pray through that.” McCown added that he is excited for what’s up ahead and will be “ready to go” for 2018. “But where we’re at right now, I feel like I want to play … I’m looking forward to the next few months, seeing what happens, and I’ll be ready to go,” said McCown

McCown, 38, finished playing out his one-year/$6M contract and is slated to become an unrestricted free-agent in March.
In 12 starts this season, McCown threw for 2,880 yards, 18 touchdowns, and 8 interceptions to go along with a 67.8 completion percentage.

UPDATE: Cowboys HC Jason Garrett says he has not met with WR Dez Bryant and reiterated that their recent signings at the position were not meant to push him out.
_______________________________________________________
“I have not met with Dez,” Garrett said at the Cowboys’ Taste of the NFL event. “Dez is on our football team, and again, we talked about some of the moves we made at the receiver position, and they’re designed to create competition there. We think that’s going to help everybody on our team.” Garrett is referring to their acquisitions of WRs Allen Hurns and Deonte Thompson.
Garrett also mentioned that he is “unsure” when owner Jerry Jones will address the matter with Bryant.
The Cowboys will almost certainly make a decision on Bryant’s future before the start of OTAs, which is next Monday, April 16th. If Bryant were to suffer any season-ending injury on the team’s premises, his $12.5M salary would become fully guaranteed for the 2018 season. That is why the Cowboys will have a decision before their offseason program gets underway.
Bryant is set to enter the fourth year of his 5-year/$70M contract ($45M guaranteed) and is due a base salary of $12.5M over the final two years of the agreement. Bryant is scheduled to carry a $16.5M cap hit for the upcoming season.
The Cowboys would free up $8.5M of cap space by releasing Bryant, while absorbing $8M of dead money.
Bryant, 29, started all 16 games this past season and caught 69 passes for 838 yards and six touchdowns.

NFL News: Raiders HC Jon Gruden says the team needs RB Marshawn Lynch “better and stronger” for the upcoming 2018 season.
Sports Illustrated writer, S.L. Price, interviewed Gruden for a featured story and asked him about his expectations for RB Marshawn Lynch.
Gruden added that the team is counting on Lynch to be their “featured back” and says he needs to stay in shape for the upcoming season: “I said to him: ‘I need Marshawn Lynch. I don’t need this part-time Lynch. I need full-time Lynch. … We need the real deal. If you’re going to put those letters on the back of your jersey, man, you’ve got to back it up, Marshawn — right? We don’t need another back, we need a feature back.” While there had been a lot of speculation regarding Lynch’s future with the Raiders, it appears his job is safe and is being depended upon to lead their backfield next season.
Lynch, 31, is set to enter the final year of his 2-year/$9M contract and stands to make a base salary of $4M for the 2018 season.
Lynch started 15 games this season and rushed for 891 yards on 207 carries (4.3 YPC) and seven touchdowns.

UPDATE: According to reports, Free-agent OT Branden Albert was arrested and charged with second-degree criminal trespass and willful obstruction of a law officer.

Police reports state that Albert was trying to enter a section of an Atlanta jewelry store which was off limits to customers, and a security guard then asked him to leave. Albert reportedly got angry and punched a hole in a cabinet, and pushed the officer. The security guard then used his taser to control the situation, but Albert pulled the prongs out and chased the officer, tackling him.

NFL News: Cardinals impending free-agent WR John Brown is expected to test his value in free agency.
Brown, a former 2014 third-round pick out of Pittsburgh State, is not far removed from being one of the league’s most explosive wide outs.
Brown accumulated 113 receptions, 1,699 yards, and 12 touchdowns in his first two seasons. Since then, he has been hindered by a sickle cell trait and a variety of injuries.
Brown’s production has taken a dip as he’s managed just 60 receptions for 816 yards and five touchdowns the last two seasons, while missing a total of seven games.
Cardinals HC Steve Wilks recognizes the impact Brown can have on their offense moving forward, but acknowledges his frequent injury history. "When you look at what he's been able to do for us over the years, a solid 'X' (outside receiver), a guy that can take the top off. Being on the other side and trying to game plan and go against him, he's definitely a threat. He's someone you've got to be concerned with. The biggest thing, if we move forward in 2018 and he's back on the roster, it's trying to make sure that he's healthy and that he can stay out there for 16-plus games. That's the key thing." Brown, 27, played out his 4-year/$2.798M rookie contract and is set to hit the open market as an unrestricted free-agent.
Stay tuned for more.

UPDATE: According to reports, the New York Jets have rescinded their contract offer to free-agent DT Ndamukong Suh.
Jets owner Christopher Johnson confirmed to reporters that they have indeed pulled their offer to Suh, despite their late push to sign him. Johnson cited that offering a large amount of money to Suh, “wasn’t keeping within their long-term plan” as a franchise. In addition, the Jets placed a firm deadline for Suh to accept their offer, which recently passed on Saturday evening.
The Jets entered the Suh sweepstakes on Friday when they reportedly extended the largest offer to the 31-year-old defensive tackle. However, they have stopped their pursuit of him just a couple of days after being considered a “serious contender” to land him in free agency.
Suh remains at his Oregon home and is still considering offers from the New Orleans Saints, Tennessee Titans, and Los Angeles Rams. He is not scheduled to take any other visits at this time.
Suh appeared in all 16 games this past season and recorded 48 total tackles, 4.5 sacks, two forced fumbles, and two pass defenses.

This Just In: According to reports, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers released RB Doug Martin.

Martin, 29, was set to enter the third year of his 5-year/$37.75M contract and was scheduled to make a base salary of $6.75M for the 2018 season.
The Buccaneers will pick up $6.75M of cap space by releasing Martin, while taking on no dead money.
Martin, a two-time Pro Bowler (2012, 2015), appeared in 11 games this season (8 starts) and rushed for 406 yards on 138 carries (2.9 YPC T-career-low) and three touchdowns.
In 2016, Martin was suspended for the final three games of the season for violating the league’s substance abuse policy, but was still unable to garner much production. In eight starts, Martin accumulated 421 yards on 144 carries (2.9 YPC) and three touchdowns.
Martin’s most recent Pro Bowl season came in 2015 when he compiled 1,402 rush yards on 288 attempts (4.9 YPC) to go along with six touchdowns. Since then, Martin has seen his production gradually decline.

Injury Update: According to reports, Colts QB Andrew Luck is heading to Los Angeles to work with throwing and strength experts and is very close to reaching a “huge milestone” in his recovery.
Luck will workout with throwing mechanics guru, Tom House, and strength coach Adam Dedeaux as he inches closer to throwing.
Returning to throwing is a big accomplishment for Luck, because it likely means that he will not require an additional surgery to his throwing shoulder.
Luck underwent surgery to repair a torn labrum last January and was expected to return at the midway point of the 2017 season. However, Luck continued to encounter setbacks, which is what ultimately led the Colts to shut him down for the entire year.
As of now, Luck continues to do functional work to get his strength back in his shoulder. He’s working on his motion and arm speed, which are two important factors for a successful recovery.
Everything seems to be headed in the right direction for Luck and the Colts are optimistic about his return for the 2018 season.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: According to reports, Bengals DT Josh Tupou was arrested last Thursday for violating a protection order.

NFL News: According to reports, Patriots HC Bill Belichick called out TE Rob Gronkowski for being a TB12 client.
In the midst of a rollercoaster offseason in Foxborough, Tom E. Curran of NBC Sports Boston dropped the latest bombshell on the fractured relationship between Belichick and Gronkowski.
Curran reports that Belichick “chastised” Gronkowski for being a client of Tom Brady’s personal trainer, Alex Guerrero.
Gronkowski was reportedly “underperforming” during training camp and it led Belichick to criticize the All-Pro tight-end for his partnership with TB12 during a team meeting.
Curran adds that it was Belichick’s way of encouraging players to use the team’s training staff instead of using outside sources, such as Guerrero.
The incident reportedly “irritated” Gronkowski for the entire season, which is what sparked him to mull over his future playing career with the Patriots. However, the expectation is that Gronkowski will remain a part of the Patriots’ organization moving forward, despite an offseason full of uncertainty.
Gronkowski, 28, is set to enter the fifth year of his 6-year/$54M deal and stands to make base salaries of $8M and $9M over the final two years of the agreement.
Gronkowski appeared in 14 games this past season and caught 69 passes for 1,084 yards and eight touchdowns.

UPDATE: Redskins senior VP of player personnel Doug Williams says they will not rule out trading S Su’a Cravens “if the price is right.” _______________________________________________________ “Su’a is a good football player. He’s on the football team right now,” Williams said, via the Washington Post. “The thing about this business, everybody is tradeable if the price is right. I think that’s how we’ve got to look at it. Cravens spent the entire 2017 season on the reserve/left squad list after contemplating retirement due to various health concerns. However, the former 2016 second-round pick was granted reinstatement from the NFL earlier this offseason and is targeting a return for the upcoming season.

NFL News: Giants QB Davis Webb says he has met with GM Dave Gettleman and HC Pat Shurmur and is trying to convince them that he can be the future quarterback of the franchise.
_______________________________________________________ “I had a conversation with Mr. Gettleman and kind of told him how I felt and my abilities as a quarterback,” Webb said, via Jordan Raanan of ESPN.com. “I think there are enough people around the facility that believe in me and believe in my work ethic and believe in my ability to play quarterback one day for this franchise. “I want them to know that I’m here to be the best teammate possible and work very hard. I know we have a high pick in the draft. But nobody really knows but two people — that is coach Shurmur and Mr. Gettleman. So there can be a lot of guessing and stuff like that.” So Webb has been introducing himself and learning the new playbook in hopes of making a strong impression on the new regime. With that, Webb is hoping to drive the team away from selecting a quarterback with their No. 2 overall pick in the upcoming 2018 NFL Draft. “Nobody knows what is going to happen,” Webb said. “It’s still a long ways away. It doesn’t really bother me either way. I’m going to compete. I’m looking forward to this season. I’m working really hard. I’m staying in shape, and this is the most driven and excited I’ve been in any offseason, I think, in my career of football.” Webb, a 2017 third-round pick out of California, completed 18 of 34 passes for 190 yards in the preseason, but did not make a regular season appearance.

Stay tuned for more.

Danny Woodhead is retiring from the NFL.
・・・
10 years! Wow, God had crazy plans for a small little kid from North Platte, NE! It’s been a wild ride and feel so blessed He allowed me to do what I loved for so long. But now it’s time to say goodbye to the game I love. First, I want to thank my Lord and Savior Jesus Christ! Without Him my career wouldn’t have been possible. He blessed me with the gifts and He paved the way. All I had to do was follow His plans for my life, and His plans were crazy awesome! Next, I want to thank my wife who has been by my side since freshman year of high school. She has been a rock through all the ups and downs. Sis, Willy, Mae Mae, and Hopie your daddy is going to be home a ton more and I can’t wait! Thanks to my Dad and Mom for always supporting me and showing me that God is first, then everything else will fall into place. Ben, Joel, and Anna thanks for preparing me for the NFL in our backyard games growing up. The dreaded in-laws Steve and Suzie for always being there for me. Chris Gittings (agent) you’re the best and thankful your my brother/uncle! Thank you Jets, Patriots, Chargers, and Ravens! Thanks to all my head coaches (Bob Zohner, Brad Smith, Bill O’Boyle, Eric Mangini, Rex Ryan, Bill Belichick, Mike McCoy, and John Harbaugh) who believed in me! To my rbs coaches (coach skiles, coach reiners, Jimmy Raye, A Lynn, Ivan, Ollie, Ridge, and Thomas) thanks for putting up with me. Thanks to all my teammates from high school till now. Without you guys I never would’ve become who I was as a player. To all my olinemen, you guys deserve the credit for anything that I received credit for. I thank you for helping make my career. To all the trainers, team docs, strength coaches, chiropractors, massage therapists, physical therapists, body gurus thanks for making sure I was on the field. To all the people who made my life easier at the facility (ops, pr, equipment staff, cafe workers, custodians) thanks and your work doesn’t go unnoticed. And how could i forget all my fans?!You’re the best and have always felt the love and support! I’m sure I’ve forgotten a few but know that I’m thankful for everything everyone has done on my journey.

Former Buccaneers RB Doug Martin thanked the organization in the following statement.
Martin was released by the Buccaneers after six seasons with the team.
The Buccaneers selected Martin in the first-round of the 2012 NFL Draft.

Developing: According to reports, the Atlanta Falcons and QB Matt Ryan are “close” to finalizing a long-term contract extension.
Falcons GM Thomas Dimitroff mentioned during an interview with 680 The Fan on Tuesday (per Matt Tabeek) that he believes they’re close to an agreement with QB Matt Ryan on a long-term extension. “I think we’re close,” Dimitroff said.

Dimitroff added that “it’s not a complicated process” and he’s “not kept up at night and it’s a priority.” Ryan, 32, is entering the final year of his 6-year/$103.75M contract and stands to make a base salary of $19.25M for the 2018 season.
Ryan started all 16 games this past season and threw for 4,095 yards, 20 touchdowns and 12 interceptions to go along with a 64.7 completion percentage.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Ravens LB C.J. Mosley says he wants to finish his career in Baltimore.
_______________________________________________________
“I’ve never been a guy that’s liked change or gone to a new place and start over,” Mosley said, via ESPN.com. “I went all four years at Bama. I was at one high school. I was at one middle school. So I’ll love to stay in Baltimore and continue my legacy and try to be the second-best linebacker to finish out there.” _______________________________________________________
Mosley, 25, is set to play out his 2018 fifth-year option and will become an unrestricted free-agent after next season.
With that being said, Mosley is confident that a long-term extension will eventually get done: “I’m pretty sure something will get worked out, but I just focus on football,” Mosley said. “I just leave that to the head of the front office and my agent. I just let them work that out. All I can do is stay healthy and play football.” “I’m not really focused on that. I feel like I put in all the work I could and shed a lot of blood, sweat and tears, so I feel like my play will do all the talking when it comes time for that.” Mosley finished the 2017 season with 132 tackles (8th in NFL), one sack, two interceptions with one of them being returned for a touchdown, three forced fumbles, and seven pass defenses.
Mosley will make a base salary of $8.7M for the 2018 season.
Stay tuned for more.

This Just In: Bills OG Richie Incognito has announced his retirement from the NFL due to health concerns.

_______________________________________________________
“I’m, done. That’s it. It’s been a long career,” Incognito said. “Went to the doctor. My liver and kidneys are shutting down. The stress is killing me. It’s just about doing what’s right. I just want to be in the Hall of Fame.” When asked about taking a pay cut this offseason, Incognito said: “It pisses me the f off. The contract and all that pissed me the f off and all that, but (retiring) has nothing to do with that.” When asked if there was a chance of him changing his mind, to which Incognito said: “Absolutely not.” Incognito, 34, ends his career as a 4-time Pro-Bowler.

Injury Update: Bengals WR John Ross says his body did not translate well to the NFL, which caused him to miss significant time during his rookie season.
Ross, the former 9th overall pick of the 2017 NFL Draft, says he didn’t respond well to the physical nature of the league: “That was the problem,” Ross said, via Geoff Hobson of Bengals.com. “My body didn’t respond the way I wanted it to. Coming in late, I didn’t get to train. I was out of shape. That was pretty tough on my body. Rushing into it. Being out of shape. My body couldn’t take the physical aspects of the game we do every day. I thought I could. I think it kind of wore me out faster than I thought.” Ross continued: “I really didn’t catch up until the end of the year when I started to have better practices. It all started to click together. It was already kind of too late. It was best to rest, get my body right.” Ross’ struggles began in training camp when he competed against Brandon LaFell, Cody Core, Tyler Boyd, and Josh Malone to be the starting wide receiver alongside A.J. Green.
Despite being a first-round pick, Bengals HC Marvin Lewis listed Ross as the sixth wide out on their official depth chart.
Ross missed the team’s regular season opener due to a knee injury, but later made his debut in Week 2 vs. Texans. Ross fumbled his first and only carry of the game and was benched after gaining only 12 rushing yards. That carry proved to be his only touch of the entire season. The same knee injury that hindered him at the beginning of the season forced him to miss Weeks 3-5. After that, Ross was only active for two of the team’s next 10 games and did not record any additional statistics.
The Bengals then placed Ross on the Injured Reserve on December 4th due to a shoulder injury.

Ross is expected to receive medical clearance to participate in OTA’s this spring, despite undergoing shoulder surgery in December.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, the Denver Broncos may consider trading back if a quarterback of their liking is not available at No. 5 overall.
The Broncos have evaluated all of the top quarterback prospects during the pre-draft process and many are led to believe that they are indeed targeting a signal caller with their 5th overall pick.
Broncos GM John Elway and the team’s coaching staff recently met with Sam Darnold, Josh Allen, and Josh Rosen. They’ve also done extensive homework on Baker Mayfield. It remains unclear as to which quarterback sits atop Denver’s draft board, but if their primary target is gone when they go on the clock, a trade back is certainly an option being discussed.
It’s possible that all four quarterbacks could come off the board before the Broncos pick, especially if there are teams that trade into the Top-4 to land one of the highly touted prospects. In that scenario, Denver would consider selecting Quenton Nelson, Bradley Chubb, and Saquon Barkley, but they’d reportedly be more inclined to move back if the right offer presents itself.
The Broncos inked QB Case Keenum to a 2-year/$36M contract in free agency, but that will not stop them from taking a quarterback early in round one.
Outside of Keenum, the Broncos currently have Paxton Lynch and Chad Kelly on their roster.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: 49ers GM John Lynch says they will move DB Jimmie Ward to cornerback for the upcoming season.
Ward, a former 2014 first-round pick, hasn’t settled into one position since entering the league. He saw action at both safety and cornerback in 2015 under Eric Mangini, before being stationed at corner in Jim O’Neil’s defensive scheme in 2016. Change continued for Ward this past season as new DC Robert Saleh used him primarily at safety.
Now, the 49ers want to experiment the idea of playing him at outside cornerback as he gets set to play out the final year of his rookie contract. “Jimmie Ward is a guy who’s played some outside corner in his career,” John Lynch said, via Matt Maiocco of CSNBayArea.com. “We’re going to experiment with that this offseason and see if that’s viable and give him some time there.” Ward, 26, appeared in seven games this past season (six starts) and recorded 32 tackles, one pass defense and one fumble recovery.
Ward’s season was cut short after suffering a fracture forearm in October.
________________________________________________________

UPDATE: According to reports, the Philadelphia Eagles and DE Brandon Graham are “no closer to an agreement” on a contract extension.
Graham has expressed his desire for a contract extension this offseason and hopes to finish his career in Philadelphia. However, Eagles VP of football operations Howie Roseman is non-committal about giving Graham the long-term deal he wants, considering the team’s current cap situation. “Brandon is a hugely valuable part of our team,” Roseman said. “Obviously, he’s in the last year of his deal and he’s one of the most productive players at his position. He deserves whatever he can get. At the same time, we have a cap and we’re trying to fit everyone in. We’re trying to fit as many good players.” Roseman also mentioned that they have a lot of players on multi-year contracts and reiterated their intention to retain as many players as they can. “We went through this yesterday – we have a lot of players who are under contract, not only for 2018, 2019, but when we get into the 2020s, and they’re good players. We want to keep as many of them around as possible and add players on top of it. That’s a challenge, that’s a puzzle that we’re trying to figure out. But it’s a good problem to have.” Graham, 29, is set to enter the final year of his 4-year/$26M contract and stands to make a base salary of $7M for the 2018 season.
Graham outplayed his contract this season as he led the team with 9.5 sacks and made the game-clinching strip sack on Patriots QB Tom Brady to close out the Eagles’ Super Bowl victory.
Graham also recorded 33 solo tackles, two forced fumbles, one fumble recovery returned for a touchdown and three pass defenses in 15 starts this season.
Stay tuned for more.

Injury Update: Jaguars QB Blake Bortles (Wrist) says he expects to be cleared for OTA’s this spring.
Bortles underwent wrist surgery after the season and says he is progressing in his rehab: "For these next two weeks to kind of get me to that six-week mark of the rehab and be 100 percent cleared, we came up with a program here that [Jaguars head athletic trainer Scott] Trulock and us talked about," Bortles said, via Michael DiRocco of ESPN. "Just as far as controlling the amount of throws, the velocity, the yardage and doing that. So that'll take place for the next two weeks, and ideally I'll be cleared and back to just my normal throwing program four days a week trying to get everything tuned up and ready to go for OTAs." Although Bortles played through the wrist injury all season, he knew surgery was needed in the offseason following a heavy dose of cortisone shots that kept him on the field: "By the end of [the season], it was kind of, they didn't want to do really any more cortisone shots, so it was a 'Let's make it through the season and get it fixed and get it right after the year,'" Bortles said.

Bortles, 25, just signed a 3-year/$54M contract extension, worth $26.5M guaranteed. His new deal can reach a max of $66.5M with incentives.

BREAKING: According to reports, 49ers LB Reuben Foster has been charged with felony domestic violence.
Here’s the official release from the Santa Clara DA:

Foster, 24, physically attacked the 28-year-old woman during a February argument at their Los Gatos home, leaving her bruised and with a ruptured ear drum.

Foster is scheduled to be arraigned at 1:30 p.m. on Thursday, April 12 in Department 44 of the Hall of Justice in San Jose. The defendant faces charges of domestic violence with an allegation that he inflicted great bodily injury, forcefully attempting to prevent a victim from reporting a crime, and possession of an assault weapon – all felonies. He is also charged with misdemeanor possession of large capacity weapon magazine. If convicted, he faces more than 11 years in prison.

Prosecutor Kevin Smith said: “Our focus is on holding accountable those who hurt their intimate partners. Our Office handles between four and five thousand domestic violence cases each year. We only hope that this case illuminates the tragic regularity of the rest.” On February 11, the victim flagged down a stranger’s car driving on Shannon Road to call 911. She called police. The victim told responding sheriff’s deputies and Los Gatos police that Foster dragged her by her hair, physically threw her out of the house, and punched her in the head 8 to 10times.

The victim went to a local hospital, where she was treated for her injuries, and released. During their search of Foster’s home, officers found the weapon – a Sig Sauer 516 – along with its large capacity magazine – both of which are illegal to possess in California.

Foster is a former first-round pick of the 49ers back in 2017. He’s entering the second year of his 4-year/$9.03M contract and stands to make base salaries of $875K and $1.28M over the next two years of the agreement.

The 49ers will have a fifth-year option to pick up in 2020, but that’s only guaranteed for injury.

Injury Update: According to reports, Texans HC Bill O’Brien says QB Deshaun Watson is ahead of schedule in his ACL rehab and could be cleared for OTA’s next month.
O’Brien added that Watson will unlikely participate in team drills, but anticipates him being cleared to do some individual work.
Watson appeared in seven games (6 starts) this past season and threw for 1,699 yards, 19 touchdowns, and eight interceptions to go along with a 61.8 completion percentage. In addition, Watson rushed for 269 yards and two touchdowns on 36 attempts (7.5 YPC). Watson, a former 2017 first-round pick, suffered a torn ACL in practice on November 2nd and underwent season-ending knee surgery six days later.

2018 NFL Draft: According to reports, There is growing belief that the New York Giants and Buffalo Bills will strike a deal involving the No. 2 overall pick.
Quarterbacks are the main driving force behind draft trades and it’s something Bills’ GM Brandon Beane has been exploring for the last several weeks.
Beane is reportedly working the phones in attempt to obtain a pick somewhere in the top-5 and there is growing belief that the Giants will be his target to execute a potential deal.
The Bills acquired the No. 12 overall pick from Cincinnati in a trade that sent LT Cordy Glenn and their 21st overall pick to the Bengals. That move was strategically done to give Buffalo the best chance to land a quarterback at the top of the draft with their two first-round picks (No. 12, No. 22) as ammo to move up. In addition, the Bills also possess the No. 53 and 56 picks in the second round and picks No. 65 and 96 in the third round.
No trade is imminent at this time, but both sides continue to be involved in active negotiations.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Bears HC Matt Nagy plans to give WR Kevin White “every opportunity to succeed.” _______________________________________________________
“For me, I really, truly mean this when I say it: I am really excited to dig deep into him and put him in the best situation possible for Kevin White to succeed,’’ Nagy said, via the Chicago Sun-Times. ‘‘Here is a guy we have on our roster that, to a lot of people, can get lost in the shuffle or just pushed to the side. That’s not going to happen. We’re going to give him every opportunity to succeed.’’ Nagy added that it’s going to be a matter rebuilding White’s confidence as a player. ‘‘For [White] right now, it’s just going to be a confidence thing,’’ Nagy said. ‘‘If we can figure out a way to get his confidence back, he has all the physical tools.’’ White, a former 2015 first-round pick (No. 7 overall), has struggled to stay healthy since entering the league.
White suffered a stress fracture in his left shin during offseason workouts that led him to miss the entire 2015 season. White was able to fully recover and started the first four games of the 2016 season. However, White suffered a fractured fibula in his left leg and was placed on the season-ending Injured Reserve.
The Bears were optimistic about White entering the 2017 campaign and listed him as a starter on their official depth chart. Unfortunately, the injury bug struck White again in Week 1 when he suffered a fractured shoulder blade vs. Falcons. The Bears later placed him on the I.R. for a third consecutive year.
In result of all his injuries, White, 25, has been limited to five career starts and has accumulated 21 receptions for 193 yards through three seasons in Chicago.
Stay tuned for more.

Bennett did not see eye-to-eye with the Packers’ medical staff and that is what ultimately led to his abrupt departure from Green Bay.
The Patriots claimed Bennett off waivers and activated him for two games this season, before placing him on the Injured Reserve due to shoulder and hamstring injuries.
Bennett is due to a $2M roster bonus at the start of the new league year: March 14th, and stands to make a base salary of $3.6M for the 2018 season.

NFL News: According to reports, Texans RB D’Onta Foreman’s charges stemming from an arrest in Austin, Texas have been dismissed.
Foreman was arrested for unlawful possession of marijuana last year. However, prosecutors agreed to drop all pending charges against him if he had no legal issues for 90 days.
Aaron Wilson of the Houston Chronicle reports that Foreman paid a $500 fine and turned in a gun found in his vehicle.
Foreman, a 2017 third-round pick, rushed for 327 yards on 78 carries (4.2 YPC) to go along with six receptions for 83 yards receiving and two touchdowns.
Foreman appeared in 10 games for the Texans this season before suffering a torn Achilles in Week 11.

NFL News: According to reports, the Cleveland Browns are expected to pursue Redskins impending free-agent WR Terrelle Pryor in the open market.
Pryor, 28, enjoyed a breakout 2016 season as a pass-catcher with the Browns where he posted 77 receptions for 1,007 yards and four touchdowns.
However, Pryor wanted to test his value in free agency last March and opted to sign a one-year/$8M contract with the Redskins instead of inking a multi-year deal to remain in Cleveland.
Pryor had every intention to return to the Browns last March, but he felt their offer was below his value coming off such a strong season. In fact, Cleveland attempted to re-acquire Pryor before this past year’s trade deadline, but were unable to finalize a deal with Washington.
As stated before, both sides have mutual interest and it makes a lot of sense for a reunion next month.
Pryor only appeared in nine games (2 starts) for the Redskins this season and hauled in 20 receptions for 240 yards and one touchdown.

NFL News: According to reports, the San Francisco 49ers and impending free-agent RB Carlos Hyde remain “far apart” in contract negotiations.
With free agency officially one week away, the 49ers have not made any progress in contract talks with Hyde.
49ers GM John Lynch mentioned that they are staying in touch with Hyde, but added that no deal is close. “We’ve had discussions with Carlos all the way through the season,” Lynch said. “We haven’t been able to come to an agreement, but those discussions are ongoing. This is a great opportunity. We have an opportunity and we will talk to all of our free agents right down to the wire. I wouldn’t say anything is imminent there.” Hyde, 27, played out the final year of his 4-year/$3.68M rookie contract and will now be looking to cash in on the open market.
Hyde is expected to test free agency, barring an unforeseen shift in contract talks, and the 49ers have started to prepare for his potential departure.
Lynch acknowledged that they held formal meetings with RB prospects Saquon Barkley (PSU), Ronald Jones (USC) and Royce Freeman (ORE), among others at the NFL scouting combine.
So while the 49ers would like to retain Hyde, they certainly don’t appear willing to meet his asking price. In result, Hyde is likely to be playing elsewhere next season.
Hyde started all 16 games this season and rushed for 938 yards on 240 carries (3.9 YPC-career low) and eight touchdowns. Hyde also caught a career-high 59 passes for 350 yards.
Stay tuned for more.

NFL News: Free-agent RB DeAngelo Williams joined ESPN as a guest host today and has not ruled out the possibility of returning for the 2018 season.

I don’t know, to be honest with you,” Williams said. “Nobody wanted me last year. Well they did, they just didn’t offer me the money that I wanted.” In 2016, Williams appeared in nine games (four starts) and rushed for 343 yards on 98 carries (3.5 YPC-T-career low) and four touchdowns. NFL News: Chiefs HC Andy Reid confirmed that Bob Sutton will return as their defensive coordinator for the 2018 season.
_______________________________________________________ “There’s nothing going on there,” Reid said when asked directly if Sutton will return (via Terez A. Paylor of the Kansas City Star). “I know everybody has their opinion on everything, just like they did when they wanted me to bench Alex Smith. That turned out pretty good. So [replacing Sutton] is not where I’m at or have ever been. I don’t listen to any of that. I do what I think is right for the Kansas City Chiefs.” Sutton has been the Chiefs’ defensive coordinator since 2013. Under Sutton, the Chiefs had the 7th ranked defense in both the 2014 and 2015 seasons. Since then, the Chiefs’ defense has regressed and has been in the bottom third of the league the past two seasons. The Chiefs finished 28th in total defense this past season.
Stay tuned for more.

Pre-Mock Draft Notes📋: As mentioned in the first post, the Jets move back to No. 11 in a trade with the Dolphins. With the pick, they snag a talented wideout in Sutton to accompany Cousins in New York.
In this portion of the draft, I have another trade going down. This time it’s the Cardinals jumping ahead of the Redskins to grab a signal caller. While it’s hard to imagine Darnold falling outside of the top-10, I think he encounters a draft day slide and finds a new home in Arizona.
As for the Bengals, I think they still get their top target in Mike McGlinchey, despite moving down three spots.
I know many draft experts are mocking Derrius Guice to the Lions at No. 20 overall, but something tells me Ronald Jones is a dark horse for Detroit if they choose to select a running back in round one. Jones is an ultra talented back that comes with good size, speed, and big play ability. Matt Patricia and Jim Bob Cooter would equip themselves with a dynamic back that would bring new life to Detroit’s stagnant rushing attack. I wouldn’t be surprised to see him go a little sooner once he impresses at the scouting combine this week.
11. New York Jets (Proposed Trade with MIA) ➡️ WR Courtland Sutton (SMU)
12. Arizona Cardinals (Proposed Trade with CIN) ➡️ QB Sam Darnold (USC)
13. Washington Redskins ➡️ LB Tremaine Edmunds (VT)
14. Green Bay Packers ➡️ DE/OLB Marcus Davenport (UTSA)
15. Cincinnati Bengals (Proposed Trade with ARZ) ➡️ OT Mike McGlinchey (ND)
16. Baltimore Ravens ➡️ WR Calvin Ridley (ALA)
17. Los Angeles Chargers ➡️ DT Da’Ron Payne (ALA)
18. Seattle Seahawks ➡️ OT Connor Williams (UT)
19. Dallas Cowboys ➡️ DT Maurice Hurst (MICH)
20. Detroit Lions ➡️ RB Ronald Jones (USC)
